CONTAGIOUS DISEASE: A disease communicable by contact with a patient suffering fromit, or with some secretion of, or object touched by, such a patient.Most such diseases have already been proved to be germ diseases, andtheir communicability depends on the transmission of the livinggerms.  Many germ diseases are not contagious, some special method oftransmission or inoculation of the germs being required.
CONTANGO: The premium or interest paid by the buyer to the seller, to beallowed to defer paying for the stock purchased until the nextfortnightly settlement day. [Eng.]
COMMONWEAL: Commonwealth.Such a prince, So kind a father of the commonweal. Shak.
CHYME: The pulpy mass of semi-digested food in the small intestinesjust after its passage from the stomach. It is separated in theintestines into chyle and excrement. See Chyle.
CONTRIVABLE: Capable of being contrived, planned, invented, or devised.A perpetual motion may seem easily contrivable. Bp. Wilkins.
COTTAGELY: Cottagelike; suitable for a cottage; rustic. [Obs.] Jer.Taylor.
CORNEULE: One of the corneas of a compound eye in the invertebrates.Carpenter.
CHARON: The son of Erebus and Nox, whose office it was to ferry thesouls of the dead over the Styx, a river of the infernal regions.Shak.
CONSPIRATION: Agreement or concurrence for some end or purpose; conspiracy.[R.]As soon as it was day, certain Jews made a conspiration. Udall.In our natural body every part has a nacassary sympathy with everyother, and all together form, by their harmonious onspiration, ahealthy whole. Sir W. Hamilton.
CHEMOSMOSIS: Chemical action taking place through an intervening membrane.
CHURCHSHIP: State of being a church. South.
CHESTNUT: The edible nut of a forest tree (Castanea vesce) of Europe andAmerica. Commonly two or more of the nuts grow in a prickly bur.
CALLIOPE: The Muse that presides over eloquence and heroic poetry; motherof Orpheus, and chief of the nine Muses.
CHANT: To sing or recite after the manner of a chant, or to a tunecalled a chant.
CONSTRICTED: Contracted or compressed so as to be smaller in certain placesor parts than in others.
CONDIMENT: Something used to give relish to food, and to gratify thetaste; a pungment and appetizing substance, as pepper or mustard;seasoning.As for radish and the like, they are for condiments, and not fornourishment. Bacon.
CORKED: having acquired an unpleasant taste from the cork; as, a bottleof wine is corked.
CALUMNIATE: To accuse falsely and maliciously of a crime or offense, or ofsomething disreputable; to slander; to libel.Hatred unto the truth did always falsely report and calumniate allgodly men's doings. Strype.Syn.-- To asperse; slander; defame; vilify; traduce; belie; bespatter;blacken; libel. See Asperse.
CINERARIA: A Linnæan genus of free-flowering composite plants, mostly fromSouth Africa. Several species are cultivated for ornament.
CADASTRAL: Of or pertaining to landed property. Cadastral survey, orCadastral map, a survey, map, or plan on a large scale (Usuallytopographical map, which exaggerates the dimensions of houses and thebreadth of roads and streams, for the sake of distinctness. Brande &C.
CLYSTER: A liquid injected into the lower intestines by means of asyringe; an injection; an enema. Clyster pipe, a tube or pipe usedfor injections.
COMPROBATE: To agree; to concur. [Obs.] Sir T. Elyot.
CROSS-CROSSLET: A cross having the three upper ends crossed, so as to fromthree small crosses.
CHARIVARI: A mock serenade of discordant noises, made with kettles, tinhorns, etc., designed to annoy and insult.
CHIROPODIST: One who treats diseases of the hands and feet; especially, onewho removes corns and bunions.
CAMPHINE: Rectified oil of turpentine, used for burning in lamps, and asa common solvent in varnishes.
COULD: Was, should be, or would be, able, capable, or susceptible.Used as an auxiliary, in the past tense or in the conditionalpresent.
CRANNIED: Having crannies, chinks, or fissures; as, a crannied wall.Tennyson.
CONTORTIONIST: One who makes or practices contortions.
COUNT: To plead orally; to argue a matter in court; to recite a count.Burrill.
COVER-POINT: The fielder in the games of cricket and lacrosse who supports"point."
CONCERTINO: A piece for one or more solo instruments with orchestra; --more concise than the concerto.
CHYMIFICATION: The conversion of food into chyme by the digestive action ofgastric juice.
CONDUCIBLE: Conducive; tending; contributing. Bacon.All his laws are in themselves conducible to the temporal interest ofthem that observe them. Bentley.
CRUSTATED: Covered with a crust; as, crustated basalt.
CHAMAL: The Angora goat. See Angora goat, under Angora.
CRUCIAN CARP: A kind of European carp (Carasius vulgaris), inferior to thecommon carp; -- called also German carp.
CORRELATE: To have reciprocal or mutual relations; to be mutually related.Doctrine and worship correlate as theory and practice. Tylor.
CORAL FISH: Any bright-colored fish of the genera Chætodon, Pomacentrus,Apogon, and related genera, which live among reef corals.
CAMP: A mound of earth in which potatoes and other vegetables arestored for protection against frost; -- called also burrow and pie.[Prov. Eng.]
COMMISSIONSHIP: The office of commissioner. Sir W. Scott.
CLOSEMOUTHED: Cautious in speaking; secret; wary; uncommunicative.
CARINARIA: A genus of oceanic heteropod Mollusca, having a thin, glassy,bonnet-shaped shell, which covers only the nucleus and gills.
CHARGEFUL: Costly; expensive. [Obs.]The fineness of the gold and chargeful fashion. Shak.
CANONIZATION: The final process or decree (following beatifacation) by whichthe name of a deceased person is placed in the catalogue (canon) ofsaints and commended to perpetual veneration and invocation.Canonization of saints was not known to the Christian church titltoward the middle of the tenth century. Hoock.
CHURCHLY: Pertaining to, or suitable for, the church; ecclesiastical.
CENTROBARIC: Relating to the center of gravity, or to the process of findingit. Centrobaric method (Math.), a process invented for the purpose ofmeasuring the area or the volume generated by the rotation of a lineor surface about a fixed axis, depending upon the principle thatevery figure formed by the revolution of a line or surface about suchan axis has for measure the product of the line or surface by thelength of the path of its center of gravity; -- sometimes calledtheorem of Pappus, also, incorrectly, Guldinus's properties. SeeBarycentric calculus, under Calculus.
COLONIAL: Of or pertaining to a colony; as, colonial rights, traffic,wars.
CHANTRESS: A female chanter or singer. Milton.
CRICOTHYROID: Of or pertaining both to the cricoid and the thyroidcartilages.
CARBONIZATION: The act or process of carbonizing.
COCAINE: A powerful alkaloid, C17H21NO4, obtained from the leaves ofcoca. It is a bitter, white, crystalline substance, and is remarkablefor producing local insensibility to pain.
COADJUST: To adjust by mutual adaptations. R. Owen.
COPTIC: Of or pertaining to the Copts.-- n.
CORRESPONSIVE: Corresponding; conformable; adapted. Shak.-- Cor`re*spon"sive*ly, adv.
CULTURE FEATURES: The artificial features of a district as distinguished from thenatural.
CIRCUMAMBIENCY: The act of surrounding or encompassing. Sir T. Browne.
CELIDOGRAPHY: A description of apparent spots on the disk of the sun, or onplanets.
COMPOSITE: Belonging to a certain order which is composed of the Ionicorder grafted upon the Corinthian. It is called also the Roman or theItalic order, and is one of the five orders recognized by the Italianwriters of the sixteenth century. See Capital.
CONJECTURABLE: Capable of being conjectured or guessed.
CURIALISM: The wiew or doctrins of the ultramontane party in the LatinChurch. Gladstone.
COMATULID: Any crinoid of the genus Antedon or allied genera.
CHASTISEMENT: The act of chastising; pain inflicted for punishment andcorrection; discipline; punishment.Shall I so much dishonor my fair stars, On equal terms to give himchastesement! Shak.I have borne chastisement; I will not offend any more. Job xxxiv. 31.
COCHLEAR: Of or pertaining to the cochlea.
CLAUSTRUM: A thin lamina of gray matter in each cerebral hemiphere of thebrain of man.-- Claus"tral, a.
COMMONITIVE: Monitory. [Obs.]Only commemorative and commonitive. Bp. Hall.
CALISTHENICS: The science, art, or practice of healthful exercise of the bodyand limbs, to promote strength and gracefulness; light gymnastics.
CONNIVE: To shut the eyes to; to overlook; to pretend not to see. [R. &Obs.] "Divorces were not connived only, but with eye open allowed."Milton.
CHYLIFICATION: The formation of chyle. See Chylifaction.
CASSATION: The act of annulling.A general cassation of their constitutions. Motley.Court of cassation, the highest court of appeal in France, which haspower to quash (Casser) or reverse the decisions of the inferiorcourts.
CONSTATE: To ascertain; to verify; to establish; to prove. F. P. Cobbe.
CUSTOMABLENESS: Quality of being customable; conformity to custom. [Obs.]
COPPERY: Mixed with copper; containing copper, or made of copper; likecopper.
CONCISE: Expressing much in a few words; condensed; brief and compacted;-- used of style in writing or speaking.The concise style, which expresseth not enough, but leaves somewhatto be understood. B. Jonson.Where the author is . . . too brief and concise, amplify a little. I.Watts.
CHOUT: An assessment equal to a fourth part of the revenue. [India] J.Mill.
CAPRA: A genus of ruminants, including the common goat.
CIRCUMFLUENCE: A flowing round on all sides; an inclosing with a fluid.
CHALK: A soft, earthy substance, of a white, grayish, or yellowishwhite color, consisting of calcium carbonate, and having the samecomposition as common limestone.
CURSTNESS: Peevishness; malignity; frowardness; crabbedness; surliness.[Obs.] Shak.
CRIMSON: A deep red color tinged with blue; also, red color in general.Theugh jour be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; thoughthey be red like crimson, they shall be as wool. Is. i. 18.A maid jet rosed over with the virgin crimson of modesty. Shak.
COMMENDATORY: A commendation; eulogy. [R.] "Commendatories to our affection."Sharp.
CLOTTER: To concrete into lumps; to clot. [Obs.] "Clottered blood."Chapman.
CITINER: One who is born or bred in a city; a citizen. [Obs.] Champan.
CRASH: To break in pieces violently; to dash together with noise andviolence. [R.]He shakt his head, and crasht his teeth for ire. Fairfax.
COCCYX: The end of the vertebral column beyond the sacrum in man andtailless monkeys. It is composed of several vertebræ more or lessconsolidated.
CREAKING: A harsh grating or squeaking sound, or the act of making such asound.Start not at the creaking of the door. Longfellow.
CONDEMN: To doom to be taken for public use, under the right of eminentdomain.
CRUCIBLE STEEL: Cast steel made by fusing in crucibles crude or scrap steel,wrought iron, and other ingredients and fluxes.
CARSE: Low, fertile land; a river valley. [Scot.] Jomieson.
CETRARIN: A white substance extracted from the lichen, Iceland moss(Cetraria Islandica). It consists of several ingredients, among whichis cetraric acid, a white, crystalline, bitter substance.
CHANDOO: An extract or preparation of opium, used in China and India forsmoking. Balfour.
CONTEMPTIBILITY: The quality of being contemptible; contemptibleness. Speed.
COMMONPLACE: Common; ordinary; trite; as, a commonplace person, orobservation.
COPLAND: A piece of ground terminating in a point or acute angle. [Obs.]
CONTRAPUNTIST: One skilled in counterpoint. L. Mason.
CYANATE: A salt of cyanic acid. Ammonium cyanate (Chem.), a remarkablewhite crystalline substance, NH4.O.CN, which passes, on standing, tothe organic compound, urea, CO.(NH)2.
CAPIVI: A balsam of the Spanish West Indies. See Copaiba.
CROTCH: A stanchion or post of wood or iron, with two arms forsupporting a boom, spare yards, etc.; -- called also crane andcrutch. Totten.
CONJUNCTLY: In union; conjointly; unitedly; together. Sir W. Hamilton.
COLLECTEDNESS: A collected state of the mind; self-possession.
CHILDE: A cognomen formerly prefixed to his name by the oldest son,until he succeeded to his ancestral titles, or was knighted; as,Childe Roland.
COURT-CRAFT: The artifices, intrigues, and plottings, at courts.
CAGIT: A king of parrot, of a beautiful green color, found in thePhilippine Islands.
CLUSTER: To grow in clusters or assemble in groups; to gather or unitein a cluster or clusters.His sunny hair Cluster'd about his temples, like a god's. Tennyson.The princes of the country clustering together. Foxe.
CERAMIC: Of or pertaining to pottery; relating to the art of makingearthenware; as, ceramic products; ceramic ornaments for ceilings.
CEMENTATION: A process which consists in surrounding a solid body with thepowder of other substances, and heating the whole to a degree notsufficient to cause fusion, the physical properties of the body beingchanged by chemical combination with powder; thus iron becomes steelby cementation with charcoal, and green glass becomes porcelain bycementation with sand.
CADGY: Cheerful or mirthful, as after good eating or drinking; also,wanton. [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]
CAPRIFOLIACEOUS: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the Honeysuckle family ofplants (Caprifoliacæ.
COROMANDEL: The west coast, or a portion of the west coast, of the Bay ofBengal. Coromandel gooseberry. See Carambola.-- Coromandel wood, Calamander wood.
CORNET-A-PISTON: A brass wind instrument, like the trumpet, furnished withvalves moved by small pistons or sliding rods; a cornopean; a cornet.
CABLET: A little cable less than ten inches in circumference.
COLLEAGUE: A partner or associate in some civil or ecclesiastical officeor employment. It is never used of partners in trade or manufactures.
CONSTITUENCY: A body of constituents, as the body of citizens or voters in arepresentative district.
CUSP: A triangular protection from the intrados of an arch, or froman inner curve of tracery.
CULMEN: The dorsal ridge of a bird's bill.
CARPER: One who carps; a caviler. Shak.
CALCAREO-SILICEOUS: Consisting of, or containing calcareous and siliceous earths.
CAMPHOR: To impregnate or wash with camphor; to camphorate. [R.] Tatler.
CHRISTOPHANY: An appearance of Christ, as to his disciples after thecrucifixion.
CURVIROSTRAL: Having a crooked beak, as the crossbill.
COCAINIZE: To treat or anæsthetize with cocaine. -- Co*ca`in*i*za"tion(#), n.
COURTEPY: A short coat of coarse cloth. [Obs.]Full threadbare was his overeste courtepy. Chaucer.
CYMENE: A colorless, liquid, combustible hydrocarbon, CH3.C6H4.C3H7, ofpleasant odor, obtained from oil of cumin, oil of caraway, carvacrol,camphor, etc.; -- called also paracymene, and formerly camphogen.
COTTONWOOD: An American tree of the genus Populus or polar, having theseeds covered with abundant cottonlike hairs; esp., the P. moniliferaand P. angustifolia of the Western United States.
CARBURETOR: An apparatus in which coal gas, hydrogen, or air is passedthrough or over a volatile hydrocarbon, in order to confer orincrease illuminating power. [Written also carburettor.]
CENTRALLY: In a central manner or situation.
CESTOID: Of or pertaining to the Cestoidea.-- n.
CARCAJOU: The wolverence; -- also applied, but erroneously, to the Canadalynx, and sometimes to the American badger. See Wolverene.
COITION: A coming together; sexual intercourse; copulation. Grew.
CASSIA: A genus of leguminous plants (herbs, shrubs, or trees) of manyspecies, most of which have purgative qualities. The leaves ofseveral species furnish the senna used in medicine.
CACAO: A small evergreen tree (Theobroma Cacao) of South America andthe West Indies. Its fruit contains an edible pulp, inclosing seedsabout the size of an almond, from which cocoa, chocolate, and bromaare prepared.
CROISSANTE: Terminated with crescent; -- said of a cross the ends of whichare so terminated.
CONFUSIVE: Confusing; having a tendency to confusion.  Bp. Hall.
CATADIOPTRICS: The science which treats of catadioptric phenomena, or of theused of catadioptric instruments.
CANNABIS: A genus of a single species belonging to the order Uricaceæ;hemp. Cannabis Indica (, the Indian hemp, a powerful narcotic, nowconsidered a variety of the common hemp.
CIRCUMSCRIPTIVE: Circumscribing or tending to circumscribe; marcing the limitsor form of.
CHESSY COPPER: The mineral azurite, found in fine crystallization at Chessy,near Lyons; called also chessylite.
COMPETITION: The act of seeking, or endevearing to gain, what another isendeavoring to gain at the same time; common strife for the sameobjects; strife for superiority; emulous contest; rivalry, as forapprobation, for a prize, or as where two or more persons are engagedin the same business and each seeking patronage; -- followed by forbefore the object sought, and with before the person or thingcompeted with.Competition to the crown there is none, nor can be. Bacon.A portrait, with which one of Titian's could not come incompetititon. Dryden.There is no competition but for the second place. Dryden.Where competition does not act at all there is complete monopoly. A.T. Hadley.
CAPO TASTO: A sort of bar or movable nut, attached to the finger board of aguitar or other  fretted instrument for the purpose of raisinguniformly the pitch of all the strings.
CUBISM: A movement or phase in post-impressionism (which see, below). -- Cu"bist (#), n.
CALCIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, calcium or lime.
CHINCHERIE: Penuriousness. [Obs.]By cause of his skarsete and chincherie. Caucer.
CENTO: A literary or a musical composition formed by selections fromdifferent authors disposed in a new order.
CONTENTIOUS: Contested; litigated; litigious; having power to decidecontroversy. Contentious jurisdiction (Eng. Eccl. Law), jurisdictionover matters in controversy between parties, in contradistinction tovoluntary jurisdiction, or that exercised upon matters not opposed orcontroverted.
CHAZY EPOCH: An epoch at the close of the Canadian period of the AmericanLower Silurian system; -- so named from a township in Clinton Co.,New York. See the Diagram under Geology.
COMPELLATIVE: The name by which a person is addressed; an appellative.
COLATURE: The process of straining; the matter strained; a strainer. [R.]
CLARITY: Clearness; brightness; splendor.Floods, in whose more than crystal clarity, Innumerable virgin gracesrow. Beaumont.
CUTTHROAT: One who cuts throats; a murderer; an assassin.
CIRCUMCLUSION: Act of inclosing on all sides. [R.]
COMPLIMENTARY: Expressive of regard or praise; of the nature of, orcontaining, a compliment; as, a complimentary remark; a complimentaryticket. "Complimentary addresses." Prescott.
CANVASBACK: A Species of duck (Aythya vallisneria), esteemed for thedelicacy of its flesh. It visits the United States in autumn;particularly Chesapeake Bay and adjoining waters; -- so named fromthe markings of the plumage on its back.
CRANTS: A garland carried before the bier of a maiden. [Obs.]Yet here she is allowed her virgin crants, Her maaiden strewments.Shak.
CANTHUS: The corner where the upper and under eyelids meet on each sideof the eye.
COWAN: One who works as a mason without having served a regularapprenticeship. [Scot.]
CONVEY: To play the thief; to steal. [Cant]But as I am Crack, I will convey, crossbite, and cheat uponSimplicius. Marston.
COUNTERBRACE: To brace in opposite directions; as, to counterbrace the yards,i. e., to brace the head yards one way and the after yards another.
COUNTRY-DANCE: See Contradance.He had introduced the English country-dance to the knowledge of theDutch ladies. Macualay.
COVET: To have or indulge inordinate desire.Which [money] while some coveted after, they have erred from thefaith. 1 Tim. vi. 10.
CONSUBSTANTIALLY: In a consubstantial manner; with identity of substance ornature.
CENTRIFUGENCE: The property or quality of being centrifugal. R. W. Emerson.
COMPSOGNATHUS: A genus of Dinosauria found in the Jurassic formation, andremarkable for having several birdlike features.
CHINK: A small cleft, rent, or fissure, of greater length thanbreadth; a gap or crack; as, the chinks of wall.Through one cloudless chink, in a black, stormy sky. Shines out thedewy morning star. Macaulay.
CATALECTIC: Wanting a syllable at the end, or terminating in an imperfectfoot; as, a catalectic verse.
CARBUNCULATION: The blasting of the young buds of trees or plants, by excessiveheat or caold. Harris.
CABURN: A small line made of spun yarn, to bind or worm cables, seizetackles, etc.
COURSEY: A space in the galley; a part of the hatches. Ham. Nav. Encyc.
CONTROVERSIALIST: One who carries on a controversy; a disputant.He [Johnson] was both intellectually and morally of the stuff ofwhich controversialists are made. Macaulay.
CHELIDONIUS: A small stone taken from the gizzard of a young swallow.-- anciently worn as a medicinal charm.
COCCOLITE: A granular variety of pyroxene, green or white in color.
CRUCIFORM: Cross-shaped; (Bot.) having four parts arranged in the form ofa cross.
CREDO: The creed, as sung or read in the Roman Catholic church.He repeated Aves and Credos. Macualay.
CENSOR: One of two magistrates of Rome who took a register of thenumber and property of citizens, and who also exercised the office ofinspector of morals and conduct.
CHIMNEY-BREAST: The horizontal projection of a chimney from the wall in whichit is built; -- commonly applied to its projection in the inside of abuilding only.
CATALAN: Of or pertaining to Catalonia.-- n.
CAULOCARPOUS: Having stems which bear flowers and fruit year after year, asmost trees and shrubs.
COMPESCE: To hold in check; to restrain. [R.] Carlyle.
CRETINOUS: Having the characteristics of a cretin. "Cretinousstupefaction." Ruskin.
CAMONFLET: A small mine, sometimes formed in the wall or side of anenemy's gallery, to blow in the earth and cut off the retreat of theminers. Farrow.
CULTIROSTRAL: Having a bill shaped like the colter of a plow, or like aknife, as the heron, stork, etc.
COCKSHUT: A kind of net to catch woodcock. [Obs.] Nares. Cockshut time orlight, evening twilight; nightfall; -- so called in allusion to thetome at which the cockshut used to be spread. [Obs.] Shak. B. Jonson.
CHLORPICRIN: A heavy, colorless liquid, CCl3.NO2, of a strong pungent odor,obtained by subjecting picric acid to the action of chlorine.[Written also chloropikrin.]
CATCHDRAIN: A dich or drain along the side of a hill to catch the surfacewater; also, a ditch at the side of a canal to catch the surpluswater.
CUMACEA: An order of marine Crustacea, mostly of small size.
CONOIDAL: Nearly, but not exactly, conical. Lindley.
CORDIALLY: In a cordial manner. Dr. H. More.
CURVINERVED: Having the ribs or the veins of the leaves curved; -- calledalso curvinervate and curve-veined.
CALLE: A kind of head covering; a caul. [Obs.] Chaucer.
CEPHALOLOGY: The science which treats of the head.
CONDITIONALITY: The quality of being conditional, or limited; limitation bycertain terms.
CLIMAX: A figure of which the parts of a sentence or paragraph are soarranged that each sicceeding one rise"Tribulation worketh patience, patience experience, and experiencehope" -- a happy climax. J. D. Forbes.
CZARINA: The title of the empress of Russia.
COLLIDINE: One of a class of organic bases, C8H11N, usually pungent oilyliquids, belonging to the pyridine series, and obtained from boneoil, coal tar, naphtha, and certain alkaloids.
CRINUM: A genus of bulbous plants, of the order Amaryllidace,cultivated as greenhouse plants on account of their beauty.
CIRRIFEROUS: Bearing cirri, as many plants and animals.
CHALCID FLY: One of a numerous family of hymenopterous insects (Chalcididæ.Many are gallflies, others are parasitic on insects.
CAVICORNIA: A group of ruminants whose horns are hollow, and planted on abony process of the front, as the ox.
CLARE: A nun of the order of St.Clare.
CHINSE: To thrust oakum into (seams or chinks) with a chisel , thepoint of a knife, or a chinsing iron; to calk slightly. Chinsingiron, a light calking iron.
CHIPPEWAYS: A tribe of Indians formerly inhabiting the northern andweastern shores of Lake Superior; -- called also Objibways.
CONGENIALLY: In a congenial manner; as, congenially married or employed.
CONCEPTUALIST: One who maintains the theory of conceptualism. Stewart.
CIRCUMLOCUTIONAL: Relating to, or consisting of, circumlocutions; periphrastic;circuitous.
COLLODION: A solution of pyroxylin (soluble gun cotton) in ethercontaining a varying proportion of alcohol. It is strongly adhesive,and is used by surgeons as a containing for wounds; but its chiefapplication is as a vehicle for the sensitive film in photography.Collodion process (Photog.), a process in which a film of sensitizedcollodion is used in preparing the plate for taking a picture.-- Styptic collodion, collodion containing an astringent, as tannin.
CONSENSUAL: Existing, or made, by the mutual consent of two or moreparties.
CADMIUM: A comparatively rare element related to zinc, and occurring insome zinc ores. It is a white metal, both ductile and malleable.Symbol Cd. Atomic weight 111.8. It was discovered by Stromeyer in1817, who named it from its association with zinc or zinc ore.Cadmium yellow, a compound of cadmium and sulphur, of an intenseyellow color, used as a pigment.
CRIZZEL: A kind of roughness on the surface of glass, which clouds itstransparency. [Written also crizzeling and crizzle.]
CONSERVE: A medicinal confection made of freshly gathered vegetablesubstances mixed with finely powdered refined sugar. See Confection.
CANTHARIDIN: The active principe of the cantharis, or Spanish fly, avolatile, acrid, bitter solid, crystallizing in four-sided prisms.
COMANCHES: A warlike, savage, and nomadic tribe of the Shoshone family ofIndians, inhabiting Mexico and the adjacent parts of the UnitedStates; -- called also Paducahs. They are noted for plundering andcruelty.
CATECHUIC: Of or pertaining to catechu or its derivatives. See catechin.
CLOWNISHNESS: The manners of a clown; coarseness or rudeness of behavior.That plainness which the alamode people call clownishness. Locke.
CARBAZOL: A white crystallized substance, C12H8NH, derived from anilineand other amines.
CANONESS: A woman who holds a canonry in a conventual chapter. Regularcanoness, one bound by the poverty, and observing a strict rule oflife.-- Secular canoness, one allowed to hold private property, and boundonly by vows of chastity and obedience so long as she chose to remainin the chapter.
CALAMISTRATION: The act or process of curling the hair. [Obs.] burton.
CLOVER: A plant of differend species of the genus Trifolium; as thecommon red clover, T. pratense, the white, T. repens, and the hare'sfoot, T. arvense. Clover weevil (Zoöl.) a small weevil (Apionapricans), that destroys the seeds of clover.-- Clover worm (Zoöl.), the larva of a small moth (Asopia costalis),often very destructive to clover hay.-- In clover, in very pleasant circumstances; fortunate. [Colloq.] -- Sweet clover. See Meliot.
CONTEMNER: One who contemns; a despiser; a scorner. "Contemners of thegods." South.
CICADA: Any species of the genus Cicada. They are large hemipterousinsects, with nearly transparent wings. The male makes a shrill soundby pecular organs in the under side of the abdomen, consisting of apair of stretched membranes, acted upon by powerful muscles. A notedAmerican species (C. septendecim) is called the seventeen yearlocust. Another common species is the dogday cicada.
CUIR BOUILLI: In decorative art, boiled leather, fitted by the process toreceive impressed patterns, like those produced by chasing metal, andto retain the impression permanently.
CONSCIONABLENESS: The quality of being conscionable; reasonableness. Johnson.
COMPLEMENTARY: Serving to fill out or to complete; as, complementary numbers.Complementary colors. See under Color.-- Complementary angles (Math.), two angles whose sum is 90°.
CLOISTRAL: Of, pertaining to, or confined in, a cloister; recluse.[Written also cloisteral.]Best become a cloistral exercise. Daniel.
CHARA: A genus of flowerless plants, having articulated stems andwhorled branches. They flourish in wet places.
CHARRAS: The gum resin of the hemp plant (Cannabis sativa). Same asChurrus. Balfour.
CASSATE: To render void or useless; to vacate or annul. [Obs.]
CRUSADE: To engage in a crusade; to attack in a zealous or hot-headedmanner. "Cease crusading against sense." M. Green.
CONSECRATOR: One who consecrates; one who performs the rites by which aperson or thing is devoted or dedicated to sacred purposes. [Writtenalso consecrater.]
COLUMELLA: A term applied to various columnlike parts; as, the columnella,or epipterygoid bone, in the skull of many lizards; the columella ofthe ear, the bony or cartilaginous rod connecting the tympanicmembrane with the internal ear.
CADUCOUS: Dropping off or disappearing early, as the calyx of a poppy, orthe gills of a tadpole.
COARSEN: To make coarse or vulgar; as, to coarsen one's character. [R.]Graham.
CHIH HSIEN: An official having charge of a hsien, or administrativedistrict, in China; a district magistrate, responsible for good orderin his hsien (which see), and having jurisdiction in its civil andcriminal cases.
CARNAUBA: The Brazilian wax palm. See Wax palm.
CERVINE: Of or pertaining to the deer, or to the family Cervidæ.
CHESTED: Having (such) a chest; -- in composition; as, broad-chested;narrow-chested.
CIRCUMVOLANT: Flying around.The circumvolant troubles of humanity. G. Macdonald.
CORSAK: A small foxlike mammal (Cynalopex corsac), found in CentralAsia. [Written also corsac.]
COMFORTER: The Holy Spirit, -- reffering to his office of comfortingbelievers.But the Comforter, which is the Holy Ghost, whom the Father will sendin my name, he shall teach you all things. John xiv. 26.
CEPACEOUS: Of the nature of an onion, as in odor; alliaceous.
CALORIE: The unit of heat according to the Frensc standard; the amountof heat requires to raise the temperature of one kilogram (sometimes,one gram) of water one degree centigrade, or from 0Foot pound.
COOLING: Adapted to cool and refresh; allaying heat. "The coolingbrook." Goldsmith. Cooling card, something that dashes hopes. [Obs.]-- Cooling time (Law), such a lapse of time as ought, taking all thecircumstances of the case in view, to produce a subsiding of passionpreviously provoked. Wharton.
CONVENTIONER: One who belongs to a convention or assembly.
CONGEST: To cause an overfullness of the blood vessels (esp. thecapillaries) of an organ or part.
COLLUTORY: A medicated wash for the mouth.
CRATER: The pit left by the explosion of a mine.
CONJUNCTIVAL: Of or pertaining to the conjunctiva.
CROSS-FERTILIZE: To fertilize, as the stigmas of a flower or plant, with thepollen from another individual of the  same species.
CHELIFORM: Having a movable joint or finger closing againts a precedingjoint or a projecting part of it, so that the whole may be ised forgrasping, as the claw of a crab; pincherlike.
CHARTERHOUSE: A well known public school and charitable foundation in thebuilding once used as a Carthusian monastery (Chartreuse) in London.
CASSOLETTE: a box, or vase with a perforated cover to emit perfumes.
CINNABAR: Red sulphide of mercury, occurring in brilliant red crystals,and also in red or brown amorphous masses. It is used in medicine.
CURCUMA: A genus of plants of the order Scitamineæ, including theturmeric plant (Curcuma longa). Curcuma paper. (Chem.) See Turmericpaper, under Turmeric.
CADETSHIP: The position, rank, or commission of a cadet; as, to get acadetship.
CANCELLOUS: Having a spongy or porous stracture; made up of cancelli;cancellated; as, the cancellous texture of parts of many bones.
CREAM: To form or become covered with cream; to become thick likecream; to assume the appearance of cream; hence, to grow stiff orformal; to mantle.There are a sort of men whose visages Do cream and mantle like astanding pool. Shak.
CLINODIAGONAL: That diagonal or lateral axis in a monoclinic crystal whichmakes an oblique angle witch the vertical axis. See Crystallization.-- a.
CUBE: A regular solid body, with six equal square sides.
CONCREATE: To create at the same time.If God did concreate grace with Adam. Jer. Taylor.
COLLUCTATION: A struggling; a contention. [Obs.]Colluctation with old hags and hobgoblins. Dr. H. More.
CORSEPRESENT: An offering made to the church at the interment of a dead body.Blackstone.
CYCLOSTOME: A division of Bryozoa, in which the cells have circularapertures.
CLOSER: The last stone in a horizontal course, if of a less size thanthe others, or a piece of brick finishing a course. Gwilt.
COIGN: A var. spelling of Coin, Quoin, a corner, wedge; -- chieflyused in the phrase coign of vantage, a position advantageous foraction or observation.
CONVEYOR: A contrivance for carrying objects from place to place; esp.,one for conveying grain, coal, etc., -- as a spiral or screw turningin a pipe or trough, an endless belt with buckets, or a truck runningalong a rope.
CLAVICORN: Having club-shaped antennæ. See Antennæ -- n.
COLONIST: A member or inhabitant of a colony.
COSTOTOME: An instrument (chisel or shears) to cut the ribs and open thethoracic cavity, in post-mortem examinations and dissections. Knight.
COUNTERTERM: A term or word which is the opposite of, or antithesis to,another; an antonym; -- the opposite of synonym; as, "foe" is thecounterterm of "friend". C. J. Smith.
CAHENSLYISM: A plan proposed to the Pope in 1891 by P. P. Cahensly, a memberof the German parliament, to divide the foreign-born population ofthe United States, for ecclesiastical purposes, according to Europeannationalities, and to appoint bishops and priests of like race andspeaking the same language as the majority of the members of adiocese or congregation. This plan was successfully opposed by theAmerican party in the Church.
COAL: A black, or brownish black, solid, combustible substance, dugfrom beds or veins in the earth to be used for fuel, and consisting,like charcoal, mainly of carbon, but more compact, and oftenaffording, when heated, a large amount of volatile matter.
COLLINE: A small hill or mount. [Obs.]And watered park, full of fine collines and ponds. Evelyn.
CHEMOSMOTIC: Pertaining to, or produced by, chemosmosis. [R.]
CUSHAT: The ringdove or wood pigeon.Scarce with cushat's homely song can vie. Sir W. Scott.
CORNU: A horn, or anything shaped like or resembling a horn.
CHARTACEOUS: Resembling paper or parchment; of paper-like texture; papery.
COMPLETORY: Serving to fulfill.Completory of ancient presignifications. Barrow.
CHARISM: A miraculously given power, as of healing, speaking foreignlanguages without instruction, etc., attributed to some of the earlyChristians.
CHIDINGLY: In a chiding or reproving manner.
COWQUAKE: A genus of plants (Briza); quaking grass.
CLOTE: The common burdock; the clotbur. [Obs.] Wyclif.
CHARWOMAN: A woman hired for odd work or for single days.
CASTIGATORY: Punitive in order to amendment; corrective.
CONTRAINDICANT: Something, as a symptom, indicating that the usual mode oftreatment is not to be followed. Burke.
CARROTY: Like a carrot in color or in taste; -- an epithet given toreddish yellow hair, etc.
CHECKERS: A game, called also daughts, played on a checkerboard by twopersons, each having twelve men (counters or checkers) which aremoved diagonally. The game is ended when either of the players haslost all his men, or can not move them.
CLUBHAND: A short, distorted hand; also, the deformity of having such ahand.
CHORIC: Of or pertaining to a chorus.I remember a choric ode in the Hecuba. Coleridge.
COUNTERBALANCE: To oppose with an equal weight or power; to counteract thepower or effect of; to countervail; to equiponderate; to balance.The remaining air was not able to counterbalance the mercurialcylinder. Boyle.The cstudy of mind is necessary to counterbalance and correct theinfluence of the study of nature. Sir W. Hamilton.
CREEPINESS: An uneasy sensation as of insects creeping on the skin.She felt a curious, uneasy creepiness. Mrs. Alexander.
CARBIDE: A binary compound of carbon with some other element or radical,in which the carbon plays the part of a negative; -- formerly termedcarburet.
COLUMBAE: An order of birds, including the pigeons.
CANTHOPLASTY: The operation of forming a new canthus, when one has beendestroyed by injury or disease.
CLERICITY: The state of being a clergyman.
CHAPEL: To cause (a ship taken aback in a light breeze) so to turn ormake a circuit as to recover, without bracing the yards, the sametack on which she had been sailing.
CASUALTY: Numerical loss caused by death, wounds, discharge, ordesertion. Casualty ward, A ward in a hospital devoted to thetreatment of injuries received by accident.
CALABOOSE: A prison; a jail. [Local, U. S.]
CAVIN: A hollow way, adapted to cover troops, and facilitate theiraproach to a place. Farrow.
CRYSTALLOMANCY: Divination by means of a crystal or other transparent body,especially a beryl.
CAMARASAURUS: A genus of gigantic American Jurassic dinosaurs, having largecavities in the bodies of the dorsal vertebræ.
CONVEXLY: In a convex form; as, a body convexly shaped.
CREDIT FONCIER: A company licensed for the purpose of carrying outimprovements, by means of loans and advances upon real securities. ]
CRINCUM-CRANCUM: A twist; a whimsey or whim. [Colloq.]
CLAYEY: Consisting of clay; abounding with clay; partaking of clay;like clay.
CHEVRETTE: A machine for raising guns or mortar into their carriages.
CAL: Wolfram, an ore of tungsten. Simmonds.
COVENT: A convent or monastery. [Obs.] Bale. Covent Garden, a largesquare in London, so called because originally it was the garden of amonastery.
CHISLEU: The ninth month of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, answering toa part of November with a part of December.
COMPATIBLE: Capable of existing in harmony; congruous; suitable; notrepugnant; -- usually followed by with.Our poets have joined together such qualities as are by nature themost compatible. Broome.
CLASSIFY: To distribute into classes; to arrange according to a system;to arrnge in sets according to some method founded on commonproperties or characters.
CHOKE-FULL: Full to the brim; quite full; chock-full.
CHLORMETHANE: A colorless gas, CH3Cl, of a sweet odor, easily condensed to aliquid; -- called also methyl chloride.
CROSS-TAIL: A bar connecting the ends of the side rods or levers of abackaction or side-lever engine.
CLEVIS: A piece of metal bent in the form of an oxbow, with the twoends perforated to receive a pin, used on the end of the tongue of aplow, wagen, etc., to attach it to a draft chain, whiffletree, etc.;-- called also clavel, clevy.
COLOCYNTH: The light spongy pulp of the fruit of the bitter cucumber(Citrullus, or Cucumis, colocynthis), an Asiatic plant allied to thewatermelon; coloquintida. It comes in white balls, is intenselybitter, and a powerful cathartic. Called also bitter apple, bittercucumber, bitter gourd.
CHA: Tea; -- the Chinese (Mandarin) name, used generally in earlyworks of travel, and now for a kind of rolled tea used in CentralAsia.
COSMORAMA: An exhibition in which a series of views in various parts ofthe world is seen reflected by mirrors through a series of lenses,with such illumination, etc., as will make the views most closelyrepresent reality.
CONTLINE: The space between the strands on the outside of a rope. Knight.
CONFIRMER: One who, or that which, confirms, establishes, or ratifies; onewho corroborates. Shak.
COMTISM: Positivism; the positive philosophy. See Positivism.
CRAP: In the game of craps, a first throw of the dice in which thetotal is two, three, or twelve, in which case the caster loses.
CAST-OFF: Cast or laid aside; as, cast-off clothes.
CONVOLUTION: An irregular, tortuous folding of an organ or part; as, theconvolutions of the intestines; the cerebral convolutions. See Brain.
COLLOQUIALISM: A colloquial expression, not employed in formal discourse orwriting.
CALOYER: A monk of the Greek Church; a cenobite, anchoret, or recluse ofthe rule of St. Basil, especially, one on or near Mt. Athos.
CAPITULAR: Of or pertaining to a chapter; capitulary.From the pope to the member of the capitular body. Milman.
CAPITALNESS: The quality of being capital; preeminence. [R.]
CROSSROAD: A road that crosses another; an obscure road intersecting oravoiding the main road.
CHESTERLITE: A variety of feldspar found in crystals in the county ofChester, Pennsylvania.
COALITE: To unite or coalesce. [Obs.]Let them continue to coalite. Bolingbroke.
CROSSBRED: Produced by mixing distinct breeds; mongrel.
CARLOCK: A sort of Russian isinglass, made from the air bladder of thesturgeon, and used in clarifying wine.
CONGO SNAKE: An amphibian (Amphiuma means) of the order Urodela, found inthe southern United States. See Amphiuma.
COOP: To confine in a coop; hence, to shut up or confine in a narrowcompass; to cramp; -- usually followed by up, sometimes by in.The Trojans coopet within their walls so long. Dryden.The contempt of all other knowledge . . . coops the understanding upwithin narrow bounds. Locke.
CONSONANTIZE: To change into, or use as, a consonant. "The vowel isconsonantized, that is, made closer in position." Peile.
CARBINEER: A soldier armed with a carbine.
COACHFELLOW: One of a pair of horses employed to draw a coach; hence (Fig.),a comrade. Shak.
CRANBERRY: A red, acid berry, much used for making sauce, etc.; also, theplant producing it (several species of Vaccinum or Oxycoccus.) Thehigh cranberry or cranberry tree is a species of Viburnum (V.Opulus), and the other is sometimes called low cranberry or marshcranberry to distinguish it.
CERBERUS: A monster, in the shape, of a three-headed dog, guarding theentrance into the infernal regions, Hence: Any vigilant custodian orguardian, esp. if surly.
CARDOON: A large herbaceos plant (Cynara Cardunculus) related to theartichoke; -- used in cookery and as a sald.
CHIRONOMY: The art of moving the hands in oratory or in pantomime; gesture[Obs.]
CHRYSOLOGY: That branch of political economy which relates to theproduction of wealth.
COMMISSIVE: Relating to commission; of the nature of, or involving,commission. [R.]
CATASTASIS: That part of a speech, usually the exordium, in which theorator sets forth the subject matter to be discussed.
CUMULATIST: One who accumulates; one who collects. [R.]
CHATWOOD: Little sticks; twigs for burning; fuel. Johnson.
CHEVELURE: A hairlike envelope.The nucleus and chevelure of nebulous star. Sir. W. Hershel.
CEREAL: Of or pertaining to the grasses which are cultivated for theiredible seeds (as wheat, maize, rice, etc.), or to their seeds orgrain.
CARYOPSIS: A one-celled, dry, indehiscent fruit, with a thin membranouspericarp, adhering closely to the seed, so that fruit and seed areincorporated in one body, forming a single grain, as of wheat,barley, etc.
CONCHO-SPIRAL: A kind of spiral curve found in certain univalve shells.Agassiz.
CONVERGENT: tending to one point of focus; tending to approach each other;converging.As many rays of light, as conveniently can be let in, and madeconvergent. Boyle.The vast dome of its cathedral . . . directing its convergent curvesto heaven. Hallam.
CHROMATIC: Proceeding by the smaller intervals (half steps or semitones)of the scale, instead of the regular intervals of the diatonic scale.
CHEMUNG PERIOD: A subdivision in the upper part of the Devonian system inAmerica, so named from the Chemung River, along which the rocks arewell developed. It includes the Portage and Chemung groups or epochs.See the Diagram under Geology.
COFFLE: A gang of negro slaves being driven to market.
CROCUS: A genus of iridaceous plants, with pretty blossoms risingseparately from the bulb or corm. C. vernus is one of the earliest ofspring-blooming flowers; C. sativus produces the saffron, andblossoms in the autumn.
CANNABIN: A pisonous resin extracted from hemp (Cannabis sativa, varietyIndica). The narcotic effects of hasheesh are due to this resin.
CAPILLATURE: A bush of hair; frizzing of the hair. Clarke.
CAWK: An opaque, compact variety of barite, or heavy spar. [Alsowritten cauk.]
CARLINE THISTLE: A prickly plant of the genus Carlina (C. vulgaris), found inEurope and Asia.
CARBOHYDRATE: One of a group of compounds including the sugars, starches, andgums, which contain six (or some multiple of six) carbon atoms,united with a variable number of hydrogen and oxygen atoms, but withthe two latter always in proportion as to form water; as dextrose,C6H12O6.
CROWNWORK: A work consisting of two or more bastioned fronts, with theiroutworks, covering an enceinte, a bridgehead, etc., and connected bywings with the main work or the river bank.
CHURCHMANLY: Pertaining to, or becoming, a churchman. Milman.
CONVENANCE: That which is suitable, agreeable, or convenient.And they missed Their wonted convenance, cheerly hid the loss.Emerson.
CHURCHY: Relating to a church; unduly fond of church forms. [Colloq.]
CENATION: Meal-taking; dining or supping. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
CONVIVIALITY: The good humor or mirth indulged in upon festive occasions; aconvivial spirit or humor; festivity.
CHORE: A small job; in the pl., the regular or daily light work of ahousehold or farm, either within or without doors. [U. S.]
CARCINOLOGY: The depertment of zoölogy which treats of the Crustacea(lobsters, crabs, etc.); -- called also malacostracology andcrustaceology.
CERYL: A radical, C27H55 supposed to exist in several compoundsobtained from Chinese wax, beeswax, etc.
CONSULAR: Of or pertaining to a consul; performing the duties of aconsul; as, consular power; consular dignity; consular officers.
CLOUGH: An allowance in weighing. See Cloff.
CTENOSTOMATA: A suborder of Bryozoa, usually having a circle of bristlesbelow the tentacles.
CONVENIENTLY: In a convenient manner, form, or situation; without difficulty.
CONVENABLE: Capable of being convened or assembled.
CUBICULAR: Belonging to a chamber or bedroom. [Obs.] Howell.
CENOZOIC: Belonging to the most recent division of geological time,including the tertiary, or Age of mammals, and the Quaternary, or Ageof man. [Written also cænozoic, cainozoic, kainozoic.] See Geology.
CURLEW: A wading bird of the genus Numenius, remarkable for its long,slender, curved bill.
COPRA: The dried meat of the cocoanut, from which cocoanut oil isexpressed. [Written also cobra, copperah, coppra.]
CHARLOTTE: A kind of pie or pudding made by lining a dish with slices ofbread, and filling it with bread soaked in milk, and baked. CharlotteRusse (, or Charlotte à la russe Etym: [F., lit., Russian charlotte](Cookery), a dish composed of custard or whipped cream, inclosed insponge cake.
CIRCAR: A district, or part of a province. See Sircar. [India]
CONGEABLE: Permissible; done lawfully; as, entry congeable.
CHANSONNETTE: A little song.These pretty little chansonnettes that he sung. Black.
CHAPFALLEN: Having the lower chap or jaw drooping, -- an indication ofhumiliation and dejection; crestfallen; discouraged. See Chopfallen.
CAMBRIAN: Of or pertaining to Cambria or Wales.
CONVULSION: An unnatural, violent, and unvoluntary contraction of themuscular parts of an animal body.
CONFATED: Fated or decreed with something else. [R.] A. Tucker.
CERATOBRANCHIA: A group of nudibranchiate Mollusca having on the backpapilliform or branched organs serving as gills.
COURAGE: To inspire with courage. [Obs.]Paul writeth unto Timothy . . . to courage him. Tyndale.
CASCARA SAGRADA: Holy bark; the bark of the California buckthorn (RhamnusPurshianus), used as a mild cathartic or laxative.
CONNATION: Connection by birth; natural union. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
CLAQUEUR: One of the claque employed to applaud at a theater.
CODIST: A codifier; a maker of codes. [R.]
CHLORHYDRIN: One of a class of compounds formed from certain polybasicalcohols (and especially glycerin) by the substitution of chlorinefor one or more hydroxyl groups.
CHOLESTERIN: A white, fatty, crystalline substance, tasteless and odorless,found in animal and plant products and tissue, and especially innerve tissue, in the bile, and in gallstones.
CANTO: The highest vocal part; the air or melody in choral music;anciently the tenor, now the soprano. Canto fermo ( Etym: [It.](Mus.), the plain ecclesiastical chant in cathedral service; theplain song.
CAFTAN: A garment worn throughout the Levant, consisting of a long gownwith sleeves reaching below the hands. It is generally fastened by abelt or sash.
CONCORPORATION: Union of things in one mass or body. [R.] Dr. H. More.
CONTENT: Contained within limits; hence, having the desires limited bythat which one has; not disposed to repine or grumble; satisfied;contented; at rest.Having food rainment, let us be therewith content. 1 Tim. vi. 8.
CANAKIN: A little can or cup. "And let me the canakin clink." Shak.
COOMB: A dry measure of four bushels, or half a quarter. [Written alsocomb.]
CARIES: Ulceration of bone; a process in which bone disintegrates andis carried away piecemeal, as distinguished from necrosis, in whichit dies in masses.
CONJUNCTION: The meeting of two or more stars or planets in the same degreeof the zodiac; as, the conjunction of the moon with the sun, or ofJupiter and Saturn. See the Note under Aspect, n., 6.
CHAMISAL: A California rosaceous shrub (Adenostoma fasciculatum) whichoften forms an impenetrable chaparral.
CAPOCH: A hood; especialy, the hood attached to the gown of a monk.
CHARACTERISM: A distinction of character; a characteristic. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
COPE-CHISEL: A narrow chisel adapted for cutting a groove. Knight.
CREATIONISM: The doctrine that a soul is specially created for each humanbeing as soon as it is formed in the womb; -- opposed totraducianism.
CANTLE: To cut in pieces; to cut out from. [Obs.] [Written alsocantile.]
CONFIRMATORY: Serving to confirm; corroborative.A fact confirmatory of the conclusion. I. Taylor.
CALIVER: An early form of hand gun, variety of the arquebus; originallya gun having a regular size of bore. [Obs.] Shak.
CULPA: Negligence or fault, as distinguishable from dolus (deceit,fraud), which implies intent, culpa being imputable to defect ofintellect, dolus to defect of heart. Wharton.
CEPHALIZATION: Domination of the head in animal life as expressed in thephysical structure; localization of important organs or parts in ornear the head, in animal development. Dana.
CHAMELEON: A lizardlike reptile of the genus Chamæleo, of several species,found in Africa, Asia, and Europe. The skin is covered with finegranmulations; the tail is prehensile, and the body is muchcompressed laterally, giving it a high back.
COUSCOUSOU: A favorite dish in Barbary. See Couscous.
CUTWATER: A sea bird of the Atlantic (Rhynchops nigra); -- called alsoblack skimmer, scissorsbill, and razorbill. See Skimmer.
CIRROBRANCHIATA: A division of Mollusca having slender, cirriform appendagesnear the mouth; the Scaphopoda.
CONCLUDENT: Bringing to a close; decisive; conclusive. [Obs.]Arguments highly consequential and concludent to my purpose. Sir M.Hale.
CATBIRD: An American bird (Galeoscoptes Carolinensis), allied to themocking bird, and like it capable of imitating the notes of otherbirds, but less perfectly. Its note resembles at times the mewing ofa cat.
CORRECTOR: One who, or that which, corrects; as, a corrector of abuses; acorrector of the press; an alkali is a corrector of acids.
CALORIFICATION: Production of heat, esp. animal heat.
CONTERMINABLE: Having the same bounds; terminating at the same time or place;conterminous.Love and life not conterminable. Sir H. Wotton.
COUNTER-PALY: Paly, and then divided fesswise, so that each vertical piece iscut into two, having the colors used alternately or counterchanged.Thus the escutcheon in the illustration may also be blazoned paly ofsix per fess counterchanged argent and azure.
CONSILIENCE: Act of concurring; coincidence; concurrence.The consilience of inductions takes place when one class of factscoincides with an induction obtained from another different class.Whewell.
CHECKMATE: To check (an adversary's king) in such a manner that escape inimpossible; to defeat (an adversary) by putting his king in checkfrom which there is no escape.
CHYLURIA: A morbid condition in which the urine contains chyle or fattymatter, giving it a milky appearance.
CHEIROTHERIUM: A genus of extinct animals, so named from fossil footprintsrudely resembling impressions of the human hand, and believed to havebeen made by labyrinthodont reptiles. See Illustration in Appendix.
COMPURGATORIAL: Relating to a compurgator or to compurgation. "Theircompurgatorial oath." Milman.
CURTAILMENT: The act or result of curtailing or cutting off. Bancroft.
COMPLICATE: Folded together, or upon itself, with the fold runninglengthwise.
CONVEYANCING: The business of a conveyancer; the act or business of drawingdeeds, leases, or other writings, for transferring the title toproperty from one person to another.
COWARDICE: Want of courage to face danger; extreme timidity;pusillanimity; base fear of danger or hurt; lack of spirit.The cowardice of doing wrong. Milton.Moderation was despised as cowardice. Macualay.
CAPON: A castrated cock, esp. when fattened; a male chicken gelded toimprove his flesh for the table. Shak.The merry thought of a capon. W. Irving.
CUMULATE: To gather or throw into a heap; to heap together; toaccumulate.Shoals of shells, bedded and cumulated heap upon heap. Woodward.
COREOPSIS: A genus of herbaceous composite plants, having the achenes two-horned and remotely resembling some insect; tickseed. C. tinctoria,of the Western plains, the commonest plant of the genus, has beenused in dyeing.
CYCAS: A genus of trees, intermediate in character between the palmsand the pines. The pith of the trunk of some species furnishes avaluable kind of sago.
CYCLOPEDIC: Belonging to the circle of the sciences, or to a cyclopedia; ofthe nature of a cyclopedia; hence, of great range, extent, or amount;as, a man of cyclopedic knowledge.
CLANGOUS: Making a clang, or a ringing metallic sound. [Obs.]
CASEIC: OF or pertaining to cheese; as, caseic acid.
COUNTERPASSANT: Passant in opposite directions; -- said of two animals.
CONNASCENT: Born together; produced at the same time. Craig.
CROFTING: Exposing linen to the sun, on the grass, in the process ofbleaching.
CROW-TRODDEN: Marked with crow's-feet, or wrinkles, about the eyes. [Poetic]Do I look as if I were crow-trodden Beau. & FL.
COATI: A mammal of tropical America of the genus Nasua, allied to theraccoon, but with a longer body, tail, and nose.
CAMBRIA: The ancient Latin name of Wales. It is used by modern poets.
CAESURA: A metrical break in a verse, occurring in the middle of a footand commonly near the middle of the verse; a sense pause in themiddle of a foot. Also, a long syllable on which the cæsural accentrests, or which is used as a foot.
CONVICINITY: Immediate vicinity; neighborhood.The convicinity and contiguity of the two parishes. T. Warton.
COLLOGUE: To talk or confer secretly and confidentially; to converse,especially with evil intentions; to plot mischief. [Archaic orColloq.]Pray go in; and, sister, salve the matter, Collogue with her again,and all shall be well. Greene.He had been colloguing with my wife. Thackeray.
CYDONIN: A peculiar mucilaginous substance extracted from the seeds ofthe quince (Cydonia vulgaris), and regarded as a variety of amylose.
CULVERTAILED: United or fastened by a dovetailed joint.
COUNTERSTEP: A contrary method of procedure; opposite course of action.
COW TREE: A tree (Galactodendron utile or Brosimum Galactodendron) ofSouth America, which yields, on incision, a nourishing fluid,resembling milk.
CONGRESSIVE: Encountering, or coming together. Sir T. Browne.
CINCTURED: Having or wearing a cincture or gridle.
CATACOUSTIC: That part of acoustics which treats of reflected sounds orechoes See Acoustics. Hutton.
CERCOPOD: One of the jointed antenniform appendage of the posteriorsomites of cartain insects. Packard.
CARDIGAN JACKET: A warm jacket of knit worsted with or without sleeves.
CARACOLE: A half turn which a horseman makes, either to the right or theleft.
CLAGGY: Adhesive; -- said of a roof in a mine to which coal clings.
CUBATION: The act of lying down; a reclining. [Obs.]
COURAGEOUS: Possessing, or characterized by, courage; brave; bold.With this victory, the women became most courageous and proud, andthe men waxed . . . fearful and desperate. Stow.
CYANURIC: Pertaining to, or derived from, cyanic and uric acids.
CROSS-EXAMINER: One who cross-examines or conducts a crosse-examination.
CONSUMMATELY: In a consummate manner; completely. T. Warton.
COMPRESSED: Flattened lengthwise. Compessed air engine, an engine operatedby the elastic force of compressed air.
CUBITAL: A sleeve covering the arm from the elbow to the hand. Crabb.
CARK: A noxious or corroding care; solicitude; worry. [Archaic.]His heavy head, devoid of careful cark. Spenser.Fling cark and care aside. Motherwell.Ereedom from the cares of money and the cark of fashion. R. D.Blackmore.
CRUNODE: A point where one branch of a curve crosses another branch. SeeDouble point, under Double, a.
CAPITOL: Of or pertaining to the Capitol in Rome. "Capitolian Jove."Macaulay. Capitoline games (Antiq.), annual games instituted at Romeby Camillus, in honor of Jupter Capitolinus, on account of thepreservation of the Capitol from the Gauls; when reinstituted byDomitian, arter a period of neglect, they were held every fifth year.
CONJUGAL: Belonging to marriage; suitable or appropriate to the marriagestate or to married persons; matrimonial; connubial. "Conjugalaffection." Milton.
COVERSIDE: A region of country having covers; a hunting country.
CONDITION: A clause in a contract, or agreement, which has for its objectto suspend, to defeat, or in some way to modify, the principalobligation; or, in case of a will, to suspend, revoke, or modify adevise or bequest. It is also the case of a future uncertain event,which may or may not happen, and on the occurrence or non-occurrenceof which, the accomplishment, recission, or modification of anobligation or testamentary disposition is made to depend. Blount.Tomlins. Bouvier. Wharton. Equation of condition. (Math.) See underEquation.-- On or Upon condition (that), used for if in introducingconditional sentences. "Upon condition thou wilt swear to pay himtribute . . . thou shalt be placed as viceroy under him." Shak.-- Conditions of sale, the terms on which it is proposed to sellproperty by auction; also, the instrument containing or expressingthese terms.
CREDENCE: The small table by the side of the altar or communion table, onwhich the bread and wine are placed before being consecrated.
CONCHOID: A curve, of the fourth degree, first made use of by the Greekgeometer, Nicomedes, who invented it for the purpose of trisecting anangle and duplicating the cube.
CORVEE: An obligation to perform certain services, as the repair ofroads, for the lord or sovereign.
COMMERCIALISM: The commercial spirit or method. C. Kingsley.
CONNATE-PERFOLIATE: Connate or coalescent at the base so as to produce a broadfoliaceous body through the center of which the stem passes; --applied to leaves, as the leaves of the boneset.
CHANFRIN: The fore part of a horse's head.
CATOPTRICS: That part of optics which explants the properties and phenomenaof reflected light, and particularly that which is reflected frommirrors or polished bodies; --- formerly caled anacamptics.
COCKTAIL: A horse, not of pure breed, but having only one eighth or onesixteenth impure blood in his veins. Darwin.
CALCULATE: To make a calculation; to forecast caonsequences; to estimate;to compute.The strong passions, whether good or bad, never calculate. F. W.Robertson.
CUCKOLDLY: Having the qualities of a cuckold; mean-spirited; sneaking.Shak.
CARACAL: A lynx (Felis, or Lynx, caracal.) It is a native of Africa andAsia. Its ears are black externally, and tipped with long blackhairs.
CORRIVALSHIP: Corivalry. [R.]By the corrivalship of Shager his false friend. Sir T. Herbert.
CIRRATE: Having cirri along the margin of a part or organ.
CANCEROUS: Like a cancer; having the qualities or virulence of a cancer;affected with cancer. "cancerous vices" G. Eliot.[1913 Webster]
CRAWLER: One who, or that which, crawls; a creeper; a reptile.
CHRONOGRAPHER: One who writes a chronography; a chronologer. Tooke.
CONVICIOUS: Expressing reproach; abusive; railing; taunting. [Obs.]"Convicious words." Queen Elizabeth (1559).
CRASIS: A mixture of constituents, as of the blood; constitution;temperament.
CICATRIZATION: The process of forming a cicatrix, or the state of beingcicatrized.
COQUETTE: A tropical humming bird of the genus Lophornis, with veryelegant neck plumes. Several species are known. See Illustrationunder Spangle, v. t.
CRUMB: To break into crumbs or small pieces with the fingers; as, tocrumb bread. [Written also crum.]
COMPASSIONATE: To have compassion for; to pity; to commiserate; to sympathizewith.Compassionates my pains, and pities me. Addison.
COUNTERPLEAD: To plead the contrary of; to plead against; to deny.
CHIMANGO: A south American carrion buzzard (Milvago chimango). SeeCaracara.
COVER: The woods, underbrush, etc., which shelter and conceal game;covert; as, to beat a cover; to ride to cover.
COMOSE: Bearing a tuft of soft hairs or down, as the seeds of milkweed.Gray.
CHISLEY: Having a large admixture of small pebbles or gravel; -- said ofa soil. Gardner.
CONFERVOUS: Pertaining to confervae; consisting of, or resembling, theconfervae.Yon exiguous pool's confervous scum. O. W. Holmes.
CALIFORNIA JACK: A game at cards, a modification of seven-up, or all fours.
CEPHALOMERE: One of the somites (arthromeres) which make up the head ofarthropods. Packard.
CRANKLE: To break into bends, turns, or angles; to crinkle.Old Veg's stream . . . drew her humid train aslope, Crankling herbanks. J. Philips.
CHONDRULE: A peculiar rounded granule of some mineral, usually enstatiteor chrysolite, found imdedded more or less aboundantly in the mass ofmany meteoric stones, which are hence called chondrites.
COUNTER-COUCHANT: Lying down, with their heads in opposite directions; -- said ofanimals borne in a coat of arms.
CLINOMETER: An instrument for determining the dip of beds or strata, pr theslope of an embankment or cutting; a kind of plumb level. Dana.
CONSTABLE: An officer of the peace having power as a conservator of thepublic peace, and bound to exeute the warrants of judicial offiers.Bouvier.
CLOWN: To act as a clown; -- with it [Obs.]Beclowns it properly indeed. B. Jonson.
COUDEE: A measure of length; the distance from the elbow to the end ofthe middle finger; a cubit.
CHARMFUL: Abounding with charms. "His charmful lyre." Cowley.
CROKER: A cultivator of saffron; a dealer in saffron. [Obs.] Holinshed.
CONTROVERSIAL: Relating to, or consisting of, controversy; disputatious;polemical; as, controversial divinity.Whole libraries of controversial books. Macaulay.
CONJOINTLY: In a conjoint manner; untitedly; jointly; together. Sir T.Browne.
COMPORTANCE: Behavior; comport. [Obs.]Goodly comportance each to other bear. Spenser.
CUNDURANGO: The bark of a South American vine (Gonolobus Condurango) of theMilkweed family. It has been supposed, but erroneously, to be a curefor cancer. [Written also condurango.]
COMRADESHIP: The state of being a comrade; intimate fellowship.
CANNINESS: Caution; crafty management. [N. of Eng. & Scot.]
COLLUSION: An agreement between two or more persons to defraud a person ofhis rights, by the forms of law, or to obtain an object forbidden bylaw. Bouvier. Abbott.
CROATIAN: Of or pertaining to Croatia.-- n.
CELADON: A pale sea-green color; also, porcelain or fine pottery of thistint.
CALLOT: A plant coif or skullcap. Same as Calotte. B. Jonson.
CATCH-MEADOW: meadow irrigated by water from a spring or rivulet on the sideof hill.
CARTOMANCY: The act of telling fortunes with cards.
CHALYBEATE: Impregnated with salts of iron; having a taste like iron; as,chalybeate springs.
CANCROID: Resembling a crab; pertaining to the Cancroidea, one of thefamilies of crabs, including the genus Cancer.
CHAIN TIE: A tie consisting of a series of connected iron bars or rods.
CROTALUM: A kind of castanet used by the Corybantes.
CRIBBLE: To cause to pass through a sieve or riddle; to sift.
CORTES: The legislative assembly, composed of nobility, clergy, andrepresentatives of cities, which in Spain and in Portugal answers, insome measure, to the Parliament of Great Britain.
CHIMPANZEE: An african ape (Anthropithecus troglodytes or Troglodytesniger) which approaches more nearly to man, in most respects, thanany other ape. When full grown, it is from three to four feet high.
CONFALON: One of a fraternity of seculars, also called Penitents.
CONGRATULATE: To address with expressions of sympathetic pleasure on accountof some happy event affecting the person addressed; to wish joy to.It is the king's most sweet pleasure and affection to congratulatethe princess at her pavilion. Shak.To congratulate one's self, to rejoice; to feel satisfaction; toconsider one's self happy or fortunate.
CANCELLATE: Consisting of a network of veins, without intermediateparenchyma, as the leaves of certain plant; latticelike.
CYPERUS: A large genus of plants belonging to the Sedge family, andincluding the species called galingale, several bulrushes, and theEgyptian papyrus.
CINCHONIDINE: One of the quinine group of alkaloids, found especially in redcinchona bark. It is a white crystalline substance, C19H22N2O, with abitter taste and qualities similar to, but weaker than, quinine; --sometimes called also cinchonidia.
CASHIERER: One who rejects, discards, or dismisses; as, a cashierer ofmonarchs. [R.] Burke.
CHATI: A small South American species of tiger cat (Felis mitis).
CONSERTION: Junction; adaptation [R.]Consertion of design, how exquisite. Young.
CHIROLOGIST: One who communicates thoughts by signs made with the hands andfingers.
COWBERRY: A species of Vaccinium (V. Vitis-id), which bears acid redberries which are sometimes used in cookery; -- locally calledmountain cranberry.
CAVEAT: A notice given by an interested party to some officer not to doa certain act until the party is heard in opposition; as, a caveatentered in a probate court to stop the proving of a will or thetaking out of letters of administration, etc. Bouvier.
CHARIOTEE: A light, covered, four-wheeled pleasure carriage with twoseats.
CIRCUMBENDIBUS: A roundabout or indirect way. [Jocular] Goldsmith.
CAMBER: An upward convexity of a deck or other surface; as, she has ahigh camber (said of a vessel having an unusual convexity of deck).
COOLISH: Somewhat cool.The nights began to grow a little coolish. Goldsmith.
CASINGS: Dried dung of cattle used as fuel. [Prov. Eng.] Waterland.
CLUMPS: A game in which questions are asked for the purpose of enablingthe questioners to discover a word or thing previously selected bytwo persons who answer the questions; -- so called because theplayers take sides in two "clumps" or groups, the "clump" whichguesses the word winning the game.
COERULIGNONE: A bluish violet, crystalline substance obtained in thepurification of crude wood vinegar. It is regarded as a complexquinone derivative of diphenyl; -- called also cedriret.
COFFEEPOT: A covered pot im which coffee is prepared,
CERCAL: Of or pertaining to the tail.
CATACOMB: A cave, grotto, or subterraneous place of large extent used forthe burial of the dead; -- commonly in the plural.
CAJUPUT: A highly stimulating volatile infammable oil, distilled fromthe leaves of an East Indian tree (Melaleuca cajuputi, etc.) It isgreenish in color and has a camphoraceous odor and pungent taste.
CELEBRANT: One who performs a public religious rite; -- appliedparticularly to an officiating priest in the Roman Catholic Church,as distinguished from his assistants.
COUNTRYWOMAN: A woman born, or dwelling, in the country, as opposed to thecity; a woman born or dwelling in the same country with anothernative or inhabitant. Shak.
CASTOR AND POLLUX: See Saint Elmo's fire, under Saint.
CHICHEVACHE: A fabulous cow of enormous size, whose food was patient wives,and which was therefore in very lean condition.
CHECKSTRING: A cord by which a person in a carriage or horse car may signalto the driver.
CLAMPER: An instrument of iron, with sharp prongs, attached to a boot orshoe to enable the wearer to walk securely upon ice; a creeper. Kane.
CHAFEWEED: The cudweed (Gnaphalium), used to prevent or cure chafing.
CARANX: A genus of fishes, common on the Atlantic coast, including theyellow or goldon mackerel.
CLAY: Earth in general, as representing the elementary particles ofthe human body; hence, the human body as formed from such particles.I also am formed out of the clay. Job xxxiii. 6.The earth is covered thick with other clay, Which her own clay shallcover. Byron.Bowlder clay. See under Bowlder.-- Brick clay, the common clay, containing some iron, and thereforeturning red when burned.-- Clay cold, cold as clay or earth; lifeless; inanimate.-- Clay ironstone, an ore of iron consisting of the oxide orcarbonate of iron mixed with clay or sand.-- Clay marl, a whitish, smooth, chalky clay.-- Clay mill, a mill for mixing and tempering clay; a pug mill.-- Clay pit, a pit where clay is dug.-- Clay slate (Min.), argillaceous schist; argillite.-- Fatty clays, clays having a greasy feel; they are chemicalcompounds of water, silica, and aluminia, as halloysite, bole, etc.-- Fire clay , a variety of clay, entirely free from lime, iron, oran alkali, and therefore infusible, and used for fire brick.-- Porcelain clay, a very pure variety, formed directly from thedecomposition of feldspar, and often called kaolin.-- Potter's clay, a tolerably pure kind, free from iron.
CIRCULINE: Proceeding in a circle; circular. [Obs.] "With motioncirculine". Dr. H. More.
COUNTERBUFF: To strike or drive back or in an opposite direction; to stop bya blow or impulse in front. Dryden.
CAPSICUM: A genus of plants of many species, producing capsules or dryberries of various forms, which have an exceedingly pungent, bitingtaste, and when ground form the red of Cayenne pepper of commerce.
COMPTROLER: A controller; a public officer whose duty it is to examinecertify accounts.
CALORIMETER: An apparatus for measuring the amount of heat contained inbodies or developed by some mechanical or chemical process, asfriction, chemical combination, combustion, etc.
CONSTUPRATION: The act of ravishing; violation; defilement. Bp. Hall.
CARBONATATION: The saturation of defecated beet juice with carbonic acid gas.Knight.
CORRIVATION: The flowing of different streams into one. [Obs.] Burton.
CROWS: A tribe of Indians of the Dakota stock, living in Montana; --also called Upsarokas.
CODDYMODDY: A gull in the plumage of its first year.
CUSHIONY: Like a cushion; soft; pliable.A flat and cushiony noce. Dickens.
CHOSE: A thing; personal property. Chose in action, a thing of whichone has not possession or actual enjoyment, but only a right to it,or a right to demand it by action at law, and which does not exist atthe time in specie; a personal right to a thing not reduced topossession, but recoverable by suit at law; as a right to recovermoney due on a contract, or damages for a tort, which can not beenforced against a reluctant party without suit.-- Chose in possession, a thing in possession, as distinguished froma thing in action.-- Chose local, a thing annexed to a place, as a mill.-- Chose transitory, a thing which is movable. Cowell. Blount.
CHEVAL-DE-FRISE: A piece of timber or an iron barrel traversed with iron-pointedspikes or spears, five or six feet long, used to defend a passage,stop a breach, or impede the advance of cavalry, etc.Obstructions of chain, boom, and cheval-de-frise. W. Irving.
CAREX: A numerous and widely distributed genus of perennial herbaceousplants of the order Cypreaceæ; the sedges.
COMPLIMENT: An expression, by word or act, of approbation, regard,confidence, civility, or admiration; a flattering speech orattention; a ceremonious greeting; as, to send one's compliments to afriend.Tedious waste of time, to sit and hear So many hollow compliments andlies. Milton.Many a compliment politely penned. Cowper.To make one a compliment, to show one respect; to praise one in aflattering way.Locke.-- To make one's compliments to, to offer formal courtesias to.-- To stand on compliment, to treat with ceremony.
CANVAS: Made of, pertaining to, or resembling, canvas or coarse cloth;as, a canvas tent.
COZEN: To cheat; to defrand; to beguile; to deceive, usually by smallarts, or in a pitiful way.He had cozened the world by fine phrases. Macualay.Children may be cozened into a knowledge of the letters. Locke.Goring loved no man so well but that he would cozen him, and exposehim to public mirth for having been cozened. Clarendon.
COBOURG: A thin worsted fabric for women's dresses.
CISMONTANE: On this side of the mountains. See under Ultramontane.
COX: A coxcomb; a simpleton; a gull. [Obs.]Go; you're a brainless cox, a toy, a fop. Beau. & Fl.
COAXINGLY: In a coaxing manner; by coaxing.
CAREEN: To cause (a vessel) to lean over so that she floats on oneside, leaving the other side out of water and accessible for repairsbelow the water line; to case to be off the keel.
CANELLA: A genus of trees of the order Canellaceæ, growing in the WestIndies.
COUNTLESS: Incapable of being counted; not ascertainable; innumerable.
CABAS: A flat basket or frail for figs, etc.; Hence, a lady's flatworkbasket, reticule, or hand bag; -- often written caba. C. Bronté.
CAESURAL: Of or pertaining to a cæsura. Cæsural pause, a pause made at acæsura.
CACAJAO: A South American short-tailed monkey (Pithecia (or Brachyurus)melanocephala). [Written also cacajo.]
CRISPER: One who, or that which, crisps or curls; an instrument formaking little curls in the nap of cloth, as in chinchilla.
COMPARATE: One of two things compared together.
CORYBANTIC: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the Corybantes or theirrites; frantic; frenzied; as, a corybantic dance.
CUPELLATION: The act or process of refining gold or silver, etc., in acupel.
CRUCIFEROUS: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a family of plants which havefour petals arranged like the arms of a cross, as the mustard,radish, turnip, etc.
CABIRIC: Of or pertaining to the Cabiri, or to their mystical worship.[Written also Cabiritic.]
CHANGE: A place where merchants and others meet to transact business; abuilding appropriated for mercantile transactions. [Colloq. forExchange.]
CAPPEAK: The front piece of a cap; -- now more commonly called visor.
COMMENSALISM: The act of eating together; table fellowship.
CITIGRADAE: A suborder of Arachnoidea, including the European tarantula andthe wolf spiders (Lycosidae) and their allies, which capture theirprey by rapidly running and jumping. See Wolf spider.
CLEAVABLE: Capable of cleaving or being divided.
CUBIT: The forearm; the ulna, a bone of the arm extending from elbowto wrist. [Obs.]
CURIALITY: The privileges, prerogatives, or retinue of a court. [Obs.]Bacon.
COPPERAS: Green vitriol, or sulphate of iron; a green crystallinesubstance, of an astringent taste, used in making ink, in dyeingblack, as a tonic in medicine, etc. It is made on a large scale bythe oxidation of iron pyrites. Called also ferrous sulphate.
CRIMINAL: One who has commited a crime; especially, one who is foundguilty by verdict, confession, or proof; a malefactor; a felon.
CNIDA: One of the peculiar stinging, cells found in Coelenterata; anematocyst; a lasso cell.
CULTURE MYTH: A myth accounting for the discovery of arts and sciences or theadvent of a higher civilization, as in the Prometheus myth.
CONTERMINATE: Having the same bounds; conterminous. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
CONCESSION: The beneficiary of a concession or grant.
CLOAK: To cover with, or as with, a cloak; hence, to hide or conceal.Now glooming sadly, so to cloak her matter. Spenser.
CARABUS: A genus of ground beetles, including numerous species. Theydevour many injurious insects.
CONCREMENT: A growing together; the collection or mass formed byconcretion, or natural union. [Obs.]The concrement of a pebble or flint. Sir M. Hale
CASCALHO: A deposit of pebbles, gravel, and ferruginous sand, in whichthe Brazilian diamond is usually found.
COLLATERAL: Descending from the same stock or ancestor, but not in the sameline or branch or one from the other; -- opposed to lineal.
CLEAR-SEEING: Having a clear physical or mental vision; having a clearunderstanding.
CHOPSTICK: One of two small sticks of wood, ivory, etc., used by theChinese and Japanese to convey food to the mouth.
COMFORTABLE: A stuffed or quilted coverlet for a bed; a comforter; acomfort. [U. S.]
CLOUDAGE: Mass of clouds; cloudiness. [R.]A scudding cloudage of shapes. Coleridge.
CHURN: A vessel in which milk or cream is stirred, beaten, orotherwise agitated (as by a plunging or revolving dasher) in order toseparete the oily globules from the other parts, and obtain butter.
CEREMONIOUSNESS: The quality, or practice, of being ceremonious.
CONGE: To take leave with the customary civilities; to bow orcourtesy.
CARNALISM: The state of being carnal; carnality; sensualism. [R.]
COMMORATION: The act of staying or residing in a place. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
CAKE: To form into a cake, or mass.
CRADLING: Cutting a cask into two pieces lengthwise, to enable it to passa narrow place, the two parts being afterward united and rehooped.
CARPOLOGIST: One who describes fruits; one versed in carpology.
CHAMPAIGN: A flat, open country.Fair champaign, with less rivers interveined. Milton.Through Apline vale or champaign wide. Wordsworth.
COEXTEND: To extend through the same space or time with another; toextend to the same degree.According to which the least body may be coextended with thegreatest. Boyle.Has your English language one single word that is coextended throughall these significations Bentley.
CENTRISCOID: Allied to, or resembling, the genus Centriscus, of which thebellows fish is an example.
CONTINUOUSLY: In a continuous maner; without interruption.-- Con*tin"u*ous*ness, n.
CURTAIL DOG: A dog with a docked tail; formerly, the dog of a person notqualified to course, which, by the forest laws, must have its tailcut short, partly as a mark, and partly from a notion that the tailis necessary to a dog in running; hence, a dog not fit for sporting.Hope is a curtail dog in some affairs. Shak.
CARPOPHORE: A slender prolongation of the receptacle as an axis between thecarpels, as in Geranium and many umbelliferous plants.
CHEMIGRAPHY: Any mechanical engraving process depending upon chemicalaction; specif., a process of zinc etching not employing photography.-- Chem`i*graph"ic (#), a.
CORNIC: Pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, the dogwood (Cornusflorida).
CENTENNIAL: The celebration of the hundredth anniversary of any event; acentenary. [U. S.]
CARBONITE: An explosive consisting essentially of nitroglycerin, woodmeal, and some nitrate, as that of sodium.
CAB: A Hebrew dry measure, containing a little over two (2.37)pints. W. H. Ward. 2 Kings vi. 25.
CHUNK: A short, thick piece of anything. [Colloq. U. S. & Prov. Eng.]
CONDOLE: To express sympathetic sorrow; to grieve in sympathy; --followed by with.Your friends would have cause to rejoice, rather than condole withyou. Sir W. Temple.
CONFIRM: To administer the rite of confirmation to. See Confirmation, 3.Those which are thus confirmed are thereby supposed to be fit foradmission to the sacrament. Hammond.
CONFETTI: Bonbons; sweetmeats; confections; also, plaster or paperimitations of, or substitutes for, bonbons, often used by carnivalrevelers, at weddings, etc.
CHICKADEE: A small bird, the blackcap titmouse (Parus atricapillus), ofNorth America; -- named from its note.
CRENELATION: The act of crenelating, or the state of being crenelated; anindentation or an embrasure. [Written also crenellation.]
CONTAINABLE: Capable of being contained or comprised. Boyle.
