COROLLACEOUS: Pertaining to, or resembling, a corolla; having the form ortexture of a corolla.
CENTENARIAN: Of or relating to a hundred years.-- n.
CASHEW: A tree (Anacardium occidentale) of the same family which thesumac. It is native in tropical America, but is now naturalized inall tropical countries. Its fruit, a kidney-shaped nut, grows at theextremity of an edible, pear-shaped hypocarp, about three incheslong. Casbew nut, the large, kidney-shaped fruit of the cashew, whichis edible after the caustic oil has been expelled from the shell byroasting the nut.
CYTOID: Cell-like; -- applied to the corpuscles of lymph, blood, chyle,etc.
CEROTYPE: A printing process of engraving on a surface of wax spread on asteel plate, for electrotyping.
CYMOSCOPE: Any device for detecting the presence of electric waves. Theinfluence of electric waves on the resistance of a particular kind ofelectric circuit, on the magnetization of steel, on the polarizationof an electrolytic cell, or on the electric condition of a vacuum hasbeen applied in the various cymoscopes.
CONTRALTO: Of or pertaining to a contralto, or to the part in music calledcontralto; as, a contralto voice.
CANADIAN: Of or pertaining to Canada.-- n.
CARNIFICATION: The act or process of turning to flesh, or to a substanceresembling flesh.
COMPLICE: An accomplice. [Obs.]To quell the rebels and their complices. Shak.
COUNTER TENOR: One of the middle parts in music, between the tenor and thetreble; high tenor. Counter-tenor clef (Mus.), the C clef when placedon the third line; -- also called alto clef.
COMPASSIONATENESS: The quality or state of being compassionate.
CELLARER: A steward or butler of a monastery or chapter; one who hascharge of procuring and keeping the provisions.
CRINGLE: An iron or pope thimble or grommet worked into or attached tothe edges and corners of a sail; -- usually in the plural. Thecringles are used for making fast the bowline bridles, earings, etc.
CRITH: The unit for estimating the weight of a
COATLESS: Not wearing a coat; also, not possessing a coat.
CONTROVERTIBLE: Capable of being controverted; disputable; admitting ofquestion.-- Con`tro*ver"ti*bly, adv.
CENTRUM: The body, or axis, of a vertebra. See Vertebra.
CAT-HOLE: One of two small holes astern, above the gunroom ports, throughwhich hawsers may be passed.
CORALLACEOUS: Like coral, or partaking of its qualities.
CRIMINATIVE: Charging with crime; accusing; criminatory. R. North.
CHARLOCK: A cruciferous plant (Brassica sinapistrum) with yellow flowers;wild mustard. It is troublesome in grain fields. Called alsochardock, chardlock, chedlock, and kedlock. Jointed charlock, Whitecharlock, a troublesome weed (Raphanus Raphanistrum) with straw-colored, whitish, or purplish flowers, and jointed pods: wild radish.
COSTEAN: To search after lodes. See Costeaning.
CROSSOPTERYGII: An order of ganoid fishes including among living species thebichir (Polypterus). See Brachioganoidei.
CERULEAN: Sky-colored; blue; azure. Cowper.Blue, blue, as if that sky let fallA flower from its cerulean wall. Bryant.
CEREBRUM: The anterior, and in man the larger, division of the brain; theseat of the reasoning faculties and the will. See Brain.
CALCIGENOUS: Tending to form, or to become, a calx or earthlike substance onbeing oxidized or burnt; as magnesium, calcium. etc.
CONFLAGRANT: Burning together in a common flame. [R.] "The conflagrantmass."  Milton.
CAPITULARY: Relating to the chapter of a cathedral; capitular. "Capitularyacts." Warton.
CHLOROUS: Pertaining to, or resembling, the electro-negative character ofchlorine; hence, electro-negative; -- opposed to basylous or zincous.[Obs.]
CATEGORICALNESS: The quality of being categorical, positive, or absolute. A.Marvell.
COMEDIENNE: A women who plays in comedy.
COLORADO BEETLE: A yellowish beetle (Doryphora decemlineata), with tenlongitudinal, black, dorsal stripes. It has migrated eastwards fromits original habitat in Colorado, and is very destructive to thepotato plant; -- called also potato beetle and potato bug. See Potatobeetle.
CLOCKWORK: The machinery of a clock, or machinary resembling that of aclock; machinery which produced regularity of movement.
CYCLOMETER: A contrivance for recording the revolutions of a wheel, as of abicycle.
CONJECTOR: One who guesses or conjectures. [Obs.]A great conjector at other men by their writings. Milton.
CONCILIATION: The act or process of conciliating; the state of beingconciliated.The house has gone further; it has declared conciliation admissibleprevious to any submission on the part of America. Burke.
CLAIMANT: One who claims; one who asserts a right or title; a claimer.
CLAMMILY: In a clammy manner. "Oozing so clammily." Hood.
COLISEUM: The amphitheater of Vespasian at Rome, the largest in theworld. [Written also Colosseum.]
COMETOGRAPHY: A description of, or a treatise concerning, comets.
CYCLOIDEI: An order of fishes, formerly proposed by Agassiz, for thosewith thin, smooth scales, destitute of marginal spines, as theherring and salmon. The group is now regarded as artificial.
CAOUTCHIN: An inflammable, volatile, oily, liquid hydrocarbon, obtained bythe destructive distillation of caoutchouc.
CONSUETUDE: Custom, habit; usage. [R.]To observe this consuetude or law. Barnes.
CLINK: To cause to give out a slight, sharp, tinkling, sound, as bystriking metallic or other sonorous bodies together.And let me the canakin clink. Shak.
CHEAP: A bargain; a purchase; cheapness. [Obs.]The sack that thou hast drunk me would have bought me lights as goodcheap at the dearest chandler's in Europe. Shak.
COARCTATE: Pressed together; closely connected; -- applied to insectshaving the abdomen separated from the thorax only by a constriction.Coarctate pupa (Zoöl.), a pupa closely covered by the old larvalskin, as in most Diptera.
CLITELLUS: A thickened glandular portion of the body of the adultearthworm, consisting of several united segments modified forreproductive purposes.
CAMBISTRY: The science of exchange, weight, measures, etc.
CHALDRON: An English dry measure, being, at London, 36 bushels heaped up,or its equivalent weight, and more than twice as much at Newcastle.Now used exlusively for coal and coke.
COEDUCATION: An educating together, as of persons of different sexes orraces. Co*ed`u*ca"tion*al (, a.
CEINTURE: A cincture, girdle, or belt; -- chiefly used in English as adressmaking term.
CATASTROPHIC: Of a pertaining to a catastrophe. B. Powell.
CHUCKLEHEADED: Having a large head; thickheaded; dull; stupid. Smart.
CANNIKIN: A small can or drinking vessel.
COTTISE: A diminutive of the bendlet, containing one half its area orone quarter the area of the bend. When a single cottise is used aloneit is often called a cost. See also Couple-close.
CRYSTALLOGENY: The science which pertains to the production of crystals.
CONTINUATOR: One who, or that which, continues; esp., one who continues aseries or a work; a continuer. Sir T. Browne.
CAIRNGORMSTONE: A yellow or smoky brown variety of rock crystal, orcrystallized quartz, found esp, in the mountain of Cairngorm, inScotland.
CALKIN: A calk on a shoe. See Calk, n., 1.
CARTRIDGE: A complete charge for a firearm, contained in, or held togetherby, a case, capsule, or shell of metal, pasteboard, or othermaterial. Ball cartridge, a cartridge containing a projectile.-- Blank cartrige, a cartridge without a projectile, -- Center-firecartridge, a cartridge in which the fulminate occupies an axialposition usually in the center of the base of the capsule, instead ofbeing contained in its rim. In the Prussian needle gun the fulminateis applied to the middle of the base of the bullet. Rim-firecartridge, a cartridge in which the fulminate is contained in a rimsurrounding its base.-- Cartridge bag, a bag of woolen cloth, to hold a charge for acannon.-- Cartridge belt, a belt having pocket for cartridges.-- Cartridge box, a case, usually of leather, attached to a belt orstrap, for holding cartridges.-- Cartridge paper. (a) A thick stout paper for inclosingcartridges. (b) A rough tinted paper used for covering walls, andalso for making drawings upon.
COSMOMETRY: The art of measuring the world or the universe. Blount.
CLASSIFIC: Characterizing a class or classes; relating to classification.
CHILD STUDY: A scientific study of children, undertaken for the purpose ofdiscovering the laws of development of the body and the mind frombirth to manhood.
CHROMATISM: The state of being colored, as in the case of images formed bya lens.
COURANT: Represented as running; -- said of a beast borne in a coat ofarms.
COPORTION: Equal share. [Obs.]Myself will bear . . . coportion of your pack. Spenser.
CREOSOL: A colorless liquid resembling phenol or carbolic acid,homologous with pyrocatechin, and obtained from beechwood tar and gumguaiacum. [Written also creasol.]
CONURE: An American parrakeet of the genus Conurus. Many species areknown. See Parrakeet.
COUNTRYSIDE: A particular rural district; a country neighborhood. [Eng.] W.Black. Blackmore.
CORBEL-TABLE: A horizontal row of corbels, with the panels or filling betweenthem; also, less properly used to include the stringcourse on them.
CARPOPHYLL: A leaf converted into a fruit or a constituent portion of afruit; a carpel.
CACHOU: A silvered aromatic pill, used to correct the odor of thebreath.
CREATURIZE: To make like a creature; to degrade [Obs.]Degrade and creaturize that mundane soul. Cudworth.
COMICALITY: The quality of being comical; something comical.
CHIEFTAIN: A captain, leader, or commander; a chief; the head of a troop,army, or clan.
CONSTRUCTION: The arrangement and connection of words in a sentence;syntactical arrangement.Some particles . . . in certain constructions have the sense of awhole sentence contained in them. Locke.
CEREBELLUM: The large lobe of the hind brain in front of and above themedulla; the little brain. It controls combined muscular action. SeeBrain.
CAVO-RILIEVO: Hollow relief; sculpture in relief within a sinking made forthe purpose, so no part of it projects beyond the plain surfacearound.
CREWEL: Worsted yarn,, slackly twisted, used for embroidery.
COHORT: A body of about five or six hundred soldiers; the tenth part ofa legion.
CONFEDERATIVE: Of or pertaining to a confederation.
CINCHONISM: A condition produced by the excessive or long-continued use ofquinine, and marked by deafness, roaring in the ears, vertigo, etc.
CHIEFEST: First or foremost; chief; principal. [Archaic] "Our chiefestcourtier." Shak.The chiefest among ten thousand. Canticles v. 10.
CONSOLATION: The act of consoling; the state of being consoled; allevationof misery or distress of mind; refreshment of spirit; comfort; thatwhich consoles or comforts the spirit.Against such cruelties With inward consolations recompensed. Milton.Are the consolations of God small with thee Job xv. 11.
COMFORTLESS: Without comfort or comforts; in want or distress; cheerless.Comfortless through turanny or might. Spenser.
CONSENT: To grant; to allow; to assent to; to admit. [Obs.]Interpreters . . . will not consent it to be a true story. Milton.
CALAMBOUR: A species of agalloch, or aloes wood, of a dusky or mottledcolor, of a light, friable texture, and less fragrant than calambac;-- used by cabinetmakers.
CHERUBIM: The Hebrew plural of Cherub.. Cf. Seraphim.
CIRCUITER: One who travels a circuit, as a circuit judge. [R.] R.Whitlock.
COUPLER: One who couples; that which couples, as a link, ring, orshackle, to connect cars. Coupler of an organ, a contrivance by whichany two or more of the ranks of keys, or keys and pedals, areconnected so as to act together when the organ is played.
CLEANER: One who, or that which, cleans.
CIRCUMJOVIAL: One of the moons or satellites of the planet Jupiter. [Obs.]Derham.
CANON BONE: The shank bone, or great bone above the fetlock, in the foreand hind legs of the horse and allied animals, corresponding to themiddle metacarpal or metatarsal bone of most mammals. See Horse.
CAMPANOLOGY: The art of ringing bells, or a treatise on the art.
CARBOLIC: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid derived from coal tarand other sources; as, carbolic acid (called also phenic acid, andphenol). See Phenol.
CERATOHYAL: Pertaining to the bone, or carts, large, below the epihyal inthe hyoid arch.-- n.
CRAVATTED: Wearing a cravat.The young men faultlessly appointed, handsomely cravatted. Thackeray.
CURVE: Bent without angles; crooked; curved; as, a curve line; a curvesurface.
CATER: A provider; a purveyor; a caterer. [Obs.] Chaucer.
CABBAGE: To form a head like that the cabbage; as, to make lettucecabbage. Johnson.
CATACROTIC: Designating, pertaining to, or characterized by, that form ofpulse tracing, or sphygmogram, in which the descending portion of thecurve is marked by secondary elevations due to two or more expansionsof the artery in the same beat. -- Ca*tac"rotism (#), n.
CAOUTCHOUC: A tenacious, elastic, gummy substance obtained from the milkysap of several plants of tropical South America (esp. theeuphorbiaceous tree Siphonia elastica or Hevea caoutchouc), Asia, andAfrica. Being impermeable to liquids and gases, and not readlyaffected by exposure to air, acids, and alkalies, it is used,especially when vulcanized, for many purposes in the arts and inmanufactures. Also called India rubber (because it was first broughtfrom India, and was formerly used chiefly for erasing pencil marks)and gum elastic. See Vulcanization. Mineral caoutchouc. See underMineral.
COESSENTIAL: Partaking of the same essence.-- Co`es*sen"tial*ly, adv.We bless and magnify that coessential Spirit, eternally proceedingfrom both [The Father and the Son]. Hooker.
CHORDEE: A painful erection of the penis, usually with downwardcurvature, occurring in gonorrhea.
CENTESIMO: A copper coin of Italy and Spain equivalent to a centime.
CAMISARD: One of the French Protestant insurgents who rebelled againstLouis XIV, after the revocation of the edict of Nates; -- so calledfrom the peasant's smock (camise) which they wore.
CONSERVANT: Having the power or quality of conservation.
CORUNDUM: The earth alumina, as found native in a crystalline state,including sapphire, which is the fine blue variety; the orientalruby, or red sapphire; the oriental amethyst, or purple sapphire; andadamantine spar, the hair-brown variety. It is the hardest substancefound native, next to the diamond.
CROW-SILK: A filamentous fresh-water alga (Conferva rivularis of Linnaeus,Rhizoclonium rivulare of Kutzing).
CACHEPOT: An ornamental casing for a flowerpot, of porcelain, metal,paper, etc.
CREEL: A bar or set of bars with skewers for holding paying-offbobbins, as in the roving machine, throstle, and mule.
CONVULSIONAL: Pertaining to, or having, convulsions; convulsionary. [R.]Lamb.
CIRC: An amphitheatrical circle for sports; a circus. [R.] T. Warton.
COWORKER: One who works with another; a co
CRAFT: A vessel; vessels of any kind; -- generally used in acollective sense.The evolutions of the numerous tiny craft moving over the lake. Prof.Wilson.Small crafts, small vessels, as sloops, schooners, ets.
CYANOPATHY: A disease in which the body is colored blue in its surface,arising usually from a malformation of the heart, which causes animperfect arterialization of the blood; blue jaundice.
CONDYLOID: Shaped like or pertaining to a condyle.
CONICO-: A combining form, meaning somewhat resembling a cone; as,conico-cylindrical, resembling a cone and a cylinder; conico-hemispherical; conico-subulate.
CATFALL: A rope used in hoisting the anchor to the cathead. Totten.
COUMAROU: The tree (Dipteryx odorata) which bears the tonka bean; also,the bean itself.
CHILDISHNESS: The state or quality of being childish; simplicity;harmlessness; weakness of intellect.
CREOSOTE: Wood-tar oil; an oily antiseptic liquid, of a burning smokytaste, colorless when pure, but usually colored yellow or brown byimpurity or exposure. It is a complex mixture of various phenols andtheir ethers, and is obtained by the distillation of wood tar,especially that of beechwood.
CALCED: Wearing shoes; calceated; -- in distintion from discalced orbarefooted; as the calced Carmelites.
CHRONOLOGY: The science which treats of measuring time by regular divisionsor periods, and which assigns to events or transactions their properdates.If history without chronology is dark and confused, chronologywithout history is dry and insipid. A. Holmes.
CONVICTIVE: Convincing. [R.]The best and most convictive argument. Glanwill.-- Con*vict"ive*ly, adv.-- Con*vict"ive*ness, n.
CHEVRONED: Having a chevron; decorated with an ornamental figure of azigzag from.[A garment] whose nether parts, with their bases, were of watchetcloth of silver, chevroned all over with lace. B. Jonson.
CADDISH: Like a cad; lowbred and presuming.
COSMOPOLITANISM: The quality of being cosmopolitan; cosmopolitism.
CARYOPHYLLIN: A tasteless and odorless crystalline substance, extracted fromcloves, polymeric with common camphor.
COUNTERMAN: A man who attends at the counter of a shop to sell goods.[Eng.]
CONGENEROUS: Allied in origin or cause; congeneric; as, congenerousdiseases. [Obs.]  Sir T. Browne.
CORNISH: Of or pertaining to Cornwall, in England. Cornish chough. SeeChough.-- Cornish engine, a single-acting pumping engine, used in mines, inCornwall and elsewhere, and for water works. A heavy pump rod orplunger, raised by the steam, forces up the water by its weight, indescending.
CRAMPFISH: The torpedo, or electric ray, the touch of which gives anelectric shock. See Electric fish, and Torpedo.
CONJUREMENT: Serious injunction; solemn demand or entreaty. [Obs.] Milton.
CHOUGH: A bird of the Crow family (Fregilus graculus) of Europe. It isof a black color, with a long, slender, curved bill and red legs; --also called chauk, chauk-daw, chocard, Cornish chough, red-leggedcrow. The name is also applied to several allied birds, as the Alpinechough. Cornish chough (Her.), a bird represented black, with redfeet, and beak; -- called also aylet and sea swallow.
CARNALLY: According to the flesh, to the world, or to human nature; in amanner to gratify animal appetites and lusts; sensually.For to be carnally minded is death; but to be spiritually minded islife and peace. Rom. viii. 6.
CLARION: A kind of trumpet, whose note is clear and shrill.He sounds his imperial clarion along the whole line of battle. E.Everett.
CONCENTRATIVENESS: The faculty or propensity which has to do with concentratingthe intellectual the intellectual powers. Combe.
COLUMBIN: A white, crystalline, bitter substance. See Calumbin.
COMPLEXIONAL: Of or pertaining to constitutional complexion.A moral rather than a complexional timidity. Burke.
CONTEMPTUOUSLY: In a contemptuous manner; with scorn or disdain; despitefully.The apostles and most eminent Christians were poor, and usedcontemptuously. Jer. Taylor.
CHLOROFORM: A colorless volatile liquid, CHCl3, having an ethereal odor anda sweetish taste, formed by treating alcohol with chlorine and analkali. It is a powerful solvent of wax, resin, etc., and isextensively used to produce anæsthesia in surgical operations; alsoexternally, to alleviate pain.
COMPRADOR: A kind of steward or agent. [China] S. W. Williams
COMPRESSION: The act of compressing, or state of being compressed."Compression of thought." Johnson.
CONCEPTIBLE: Capable of being conceived; conceivable. Sir M. Hale.
CORINTHIAN: Of or pertaining to the Corinthian order of architecture,invented by the Greeks, but more commonly used by the Romans.This is the lightest and most ornamental of the three orders used bythe Greeks. Parker.
COOPTATE: To choose; to elect; to coöpt. [Obs.] Cockeram.
CISELURE: The process of chasing on metals; also, the work thus chased.Weale.
CAPTIVATE: Taken prisoner; made captive; insnared; charmed.Women have been captivate ere now. Shak.
CILICIOUS: Made, or consisting, of hair. [Obs.]A Cilicious or sackcloth habit. Sir T. Browne.
COSTMARY: A garden plant (Chrysanthemum Balsamita) having a strongbalsamic smell, and nearly allied to tansy. It is used as a pot herband salad plant and in flavoring ale and beer. Called also alecost.
COMPLACENT: Self-satisfied; contented; kindly; as, a complacent temper; acomplacent smile.They look up with a sort of complacent awe . . . to kings. Burke.
COTYLIFORM: Shaped like a cotyle or a cup.
CAULINE: Growing immediately on a caulis; of or pertaining to a caulis.
CONQUEROR: One who conquers. The Conqueror (Eng. Hist.). William theNorman (1027-1067) who invaded England, defeated Harold in the battleof Hastings, and was crowned king, in 1066.
CENTENNIAL STATE: Colorado; -- a nickname alluding to the fact that it wasadmitted to the Union in the centennial year, 1876.
COMPO: Short for Composition; -- used, esp. in England, colloq. invarious trade applications; as :(a) A mortar made of sand and cement.(b) A carver's mixture of resin, whiting, and glue, used  instead ofplaster of Paris for ornamenting walls and cornices.(c) A composition for billiard balls.(d) A preparation of which printer's rollers are made.(e) A preparation used in currying leather.(f) Composition paid by a debtor.
COUNTESS: The wife of an earl in the British peerage, or of a count inthe Continental nobility; also, a lady possessed of the same dignityin her own right. See the Note under Count.
CONTRABASS: , n. (Mus.) Double bass; -- applied to any instrument of thesame deep range as the stringed double bass; as, the contrabassophicleide; the cotrabass tuba or bombardon.
CARDIOSPHYGMOGRAPH: A combination of cardiograph and shygmograph.
COARSE-GRAINED: Having a coarse grain or texture, as wood; hence, wanting inrefinement.
CONTORTUPLICATE: Plaited lengthwise and twisted in addition, as the bud of themorning-glory. Gray.
CRUMMABLE: Capable of being crumbed or broken into small pieces.
CIRCLE: An instrument of observation, the graduated limb of whichconsists of an entire circle.
CAJUN: In Louisiana, a person reputed to be Acadian French descent.
CHORAL: Of or pertaining to a choir or chorus; singing, sung, oradapted to be sung, in chorus or harmony. Choral service, a serviceof song.
CELLA: The part inclosed within the walls of an ancient temple, asdistinguished from the open porticoes.
CERASTES: A genus of poisonous African serpents, with a horny scale overeach eye; the horned viper.
COCCOLITH: One of a kind of minute, calcareous bodies, probably vegetable,often abundant in deep-sea mud.
CANNIBAL: A human being that eats human flesh; hence, any that devoursits own kind. Darwin.
CENOTAPHY: A cenotaph. [R.]Lord Cobham honored him with a cenotaphy. Macaulay.
CROOKEDNESS: The condition or quality of being crooked; hence, deformity ofbody or of mind; deviation from moral rectitude; perverseness.
CATARRH: An inflammatory affection of any mucous membrane, in whichthere are congestion, swelling, and an altertion in the quantity andquality of mucus secreted; as catarrh of the stomach; catarrh of thebladder.
CETIN: A white, waxy substance, forming the essential part ofspermaceti.
CROWN-SAW: A saw in the form of a hollow cylinder, with teeth on the endor edge, and operated by a rotative motion.
CINNABARINE: Pertaining to, or resembling, cinnabar; consisting of cinnabar,or containing it; as, cinnabarine sand.
CALUMBIN: A bitter principle extracted as a white crystalline substancefrom the calumba root. [Written also colombin, and columbin]
COMPARTITION: The act of dividing into parts or compartments; division; also,a division or compartment. [Obs.]Their temples . . . needed no compartitions. Sir H. Wotton.
CRASPEDOTE: Of or pertaining to the Craspedota.
CARBURETED: Combined with carbon in the manner of a carburet or carbide.
CLUMSILY: In a clumsy manner; awkwardly; as, to walk clumsily.
CREOLE STATE: Louisiana; -- a nickname. See Creole, n. & a.
CLAYES: Wattles, or hurdles, made with stakes interwoven with osiers,to cover lodgments. [Obs.]
CLOISONNE: Inlaid between partitions: -- said of enamel when the lineswhich divide the different patches of fields are composed of a kindof metal wire secured to the ground; as distinguished from champlevéenamel, in which the ground is engraved or scooped out to receive theenamel. S. Wells Williams.
CHRONOGRAM: Belonging to a chronogram, or containing one.
CANONSHIP: Of pertaining to Canopus in egypt; as, the Canopic vases, usedin embalming.
CONVERTER: A retort, used in the Bessemer process, in which molten castiron is decarburized and converted into steel by a blast of airforced through the liquid metal.
CANCRINE: Having the qualities of a crab; crablike.
COLLATION: The gathering and examination of sheets preparatory to binding.
CLATTER: To make a rattling noise with.You clatter still your brazen kettle. Swift.
CATAPULT: An engine somewhat resembling a massive crossbow, used by theancient Greeks and Romans for throwing stones, arrows, spears, etc.
CANDLEWASTER: One who consumes candles by being up late for study ordissipation.A bookworm, a candlewaster. B. Jonson.
CORPUS: A body, living or dead; the corporeal substance of a thing.Corpus callosum (k; pl. Corpora callosa (-s Etym: [NL., callous body](Anat.), the great band of commissural fibers uniting the cerebralhemispheries. See Brain.-- Corpus Christi (kr Etym: [L., body of Christ] (R. C. Ch.), afestival in honor of the eucharist, observed on the Thursday afterTrinity Sunday.-- Corpus Christi cloth. Same as Pyx cloth, under Pyx.-- Corpus delicti (d Etym: [L., the body of the crime] (Law), thesubstantial and fundamental fact of the comission of a crime; theproofs essential to establish a crime.-- Corpus luteum (l; pl. Corpora lutea (-. Etym: [NL., luteous body](Anat.), the reddish yellow mass which fills a ruptured Grafianfollicle in the mammalian ovary.-- Corpus striatum (str; pl. Corpora striata (-t. Etym: [NL.,striate body] (Anat.), a ridge in the wall of each lateral ventricleof the brain.
CASCARON: Lit., an eggshell; hence, an eggshell filled with confetti tobe thrown during balls, carnivals, etc. [Western U. S.]
CRAGGEDNESS: The quality or state of being cragged; cragginess.
CHANGE GEAR: A gear by means of which the speed of machinery or of a vehiclemay be changed while that of the propelling engine or motor remainsconstant; -- called also change-speed gear.
COALMOUSE: A small species of titmouse, with a black head; the coletit.
CONCATENATION: A series of links united; a series or order of things dependingon each other, as if linked together; a chain, a succession.The stoics affirmed a fatal, unchangeable concatenation of causes,reaching even to the illicit acts of man's will. South.A concatenation of explosions. W. Irving.
COUSINRY: A body or collection of cousins; the whole number of personswho stand in the relation of cousins to a given person or persons.
CONSECRATORY: Of or pertaining to the act of consecration; dedicatory.The consecratory prayer. Bp. Burnet.
CHARY: Careful; wary; cautious; not rash, reckless, or spendthrift;saving; frugal.His rising reputation made him more chary of his fame. Jeffrey.
COMPLIABLE: Capable of bending or yielding; apt to yield; compliant.Another compliable mind. Milton.The Jews . . . had made their religion compliable, and accemodated totheir passions. Jortin.
CLIQUE: A narrow circle of persons associated by common interests orfor the accomplishment of a common purpose; -- generally used in abad sense.
COBBLESTONE: A large pebble; a rounded stone not too large to be handled; asmall boulder; -- used for paving streets and for other purposes.
CREAM-FACED: White or pale, as the effect of fear, or as the naturalcomplexion.Thou cream-faced loon. Shak.
CAESAR: A Roman emperor, as being the successor of Augustus Cæsar.Hence, a kaiser, or emperor of Germany, or any emperor or powerfulruler. See Kaiser, Kesar.Malborough anticipated the day when he would be servilely flatteredand courted by Cæsar on one side and by Louis the Great on the other.Macaulay.
COUNTERPLOT: To oppose, as another plot, by plotting; to attempt tofrustrate, as a stratagem, by stratagem.Every wile had proved abortive, every plot had been counterplotted.De Quinsey.
COMMITTIBLE: Capable of being committed; liable to be committed. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
CONTEMPERATURE: The condition of being tempered; proportionate mixture;temperature. [Obs.]The different contemperature of the elements. SDouth.
CIZAR: To clip with scissors. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
CARRION: Of or pertaining to dead and putrefying carcasses; feeding oncarrion.A prey for carrion kites. Shak.Carrion beetle (Zoöl.), any beetle that feeds habitually on deadanimals; -- also called sexton beetle and burying beetle. There aremany kinds, belonging mostly to the family Silphidæ.-- Carrion buzzard (Zoöl.), a South American bird of several speciesand genera (as Ibycter, Milvago, and Polyborus), which act asscavengers. See Caracara.-- Carrion crow, the common European crow (Corvus corone) whichfeeds on carrion, insects, fruits, and seeds.
CONNECT: To join, unite, or cohere; to have a close relation; as, oneline of railroad connects with another; one argument connect withanother.
CORRUGENT: Drawing together; contracting; -- said of the corrugator.[Obs.]
CALORIMETRIC: Of or pertaining to process of using the calorimeter.Satisfactory calorimetric results. Nichol.
CUSTODIANSHIP: Office or duty of a custodian.
CEPHALOMETER: An instrument measuring the dimensions of the head of a fetusduring delivery.
CREMATORY: Pertaining to, or employed in, cremation.
CHAMBERED: Having a chamber or chambers; as, a chambered shell; achambered gun.
CAMPHORATE: To impregnate or treat with camphor.
COGNATI: Relatives by the mother's side. Wharton.
CADDY: A small box, can, or chest to keep tea in.
CORRUGATION: The act corrugating; contraction into wrinkles or alternateridges and grooves.
CONGEALEDNESS: The state of being congealed.  Dr. H.More.
COLLOTYPE: A photomechanical print made directly from a hardened film ofgelatin or other colloid; also, the process of making such prints.According to one method, the film is sensitized with potassiumdichromate and exposed to light under a reversed negative. After thedichromate has been washed out, the film is soaked in glycerin andwater. As this treatment causes swelling in those parts of the filmwhich have been acted on by light, a plate results from whichimpressions can be taken with prepared ink. The albertype, phototype,and heliotype are collotypes.
CHEERFUL: Having or showing good spirits or joy; cheering; cheery;contented; happy; joyful; lively; animated; willing.To entertain a cheerful disposition. Shak.The cheerful birds of sundry kind Do chant sweet music. Spenser.A cheerful confidence in the mercy of God. Macaulay.This general applause and cheerful shout. Shak.
CARIBOU: The American reindeer, especially the common or woodlandspecies (Rangifer Caribou). Barren Ground caribou. See under Barren.-- Woodland caribou, the common reindeer (Rangifer Caribou) of thenorthern forests of America.
CARDIOSCLEROSIS: Induration of the heart, caused by development of fibroustissue in the cardiac muscle.
CLUCK: To make the noise, or utter the call, of a brooding hen. Ray.
CIERGE: A wax candle used in religous rites.
CARAVEL: A name given to several kinds of vessels.(a) The caravel of the 16th century was a small vessel with broadbows, high, narrow poop, four masts, and lateen sails. Columbuscommanded three caravels on his great voyage.(b) A Portuguese vessel of 100 or 150 tons burden.(c) A small fishing boat used on the French coast.(d) A Turkish man-of-war.
COADVENTURE: An adventure in which two or more persons are partakers.
CONTRADISTINGUISH: To distinguish by a contrast of opposite qualities.These are our complex ideas of soul and body, as contradistinguished.Locke.
CALAMANDER WOOD: A valuable furniture wood from India and Ceylon, of a hazel-brown color, with black stripes, very hard in texture. It is aspecies of ebony, and is obtained from the Diospyros qusesita. Calledalso Coromandel wood.
CRINOIDEA: A large class of Echinodermata, including numerous extinctfamilies and genera, but comparatively few living ones. Most of thefossil species, like some that are recent, were attached by a jointedstem. See Blastoidea, Cystoidea, Comatula.
CORPORALLY: In or with the body; bodily; as, to be corporally present.Sharp.
COCKLEBUR: A coarse, composite weed, having a rough or prickly fruit; oneof several species of the genus Xanthium; -- called also clotbur.
CORRIDOR: A gallery or passageway leading to several apartments of ahouse.
CALEFACTOR: A heater; one who, or that which, makes hot, as a stove, etc.
COSMOGONY: The creation of the world or universe; a theory or account ofsuch creation; as, the poetical cosmogony of Hesoid; the cosmogoniesof Thales, Anaxagoras, and Plato.The cosmogony or creation of the world has puzzled philosophers ofall ages. Goldsmith.
COPYHOLDER: One possessed of land in copyhold.
CHUCKLEHEAD: A person with a large head; a numskull; a dunce. [Low] Knowles.
CONFESSIONAL: The recess, seat, or inclosed place, where a priest sits tohear confessions; often a small structure furnished with a seat forthe priest and with a window or aperture so that the penitent who isoutside may whisper into the priest's ear without being seen by himor heard by others.
CONTRAPLEX: Pertaining to the sending of two messages in oppositedirections at the same time.
CONSIDERATOR: One who considers. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
COALITIONIST: One who joins or promotes a coalition; one who advocatescoalition.
CHONDRITE: A meteoric stone characterized by the presence of chondrules.
CROCONATE: A salt formed by the union of croconic acid with a base.
CANT: A segment forming a side piece in the head of a cask. Knight.
COVERT: Under cover, authority or protection; as, a feme covert, amarried woman who is considered as being under the protection andcontrol of her husband. Covert way, (Fort.) See Covered way, underCovered.
CIRCUM-: A Latin preposition, used as a prefix in many English words,and signifying around or about.
COMMUTATIVE: Relative to exchange; interchangeable; reciprocal.-- Com*mut"a*tive"ly, adv.Rich traders, from their success, are presumed . . . to havecultivated an habitual regard to commutative justice. Burke.
CHIEFAGE: A tribute by the head; a capitation tax. [Written also chevageand chivage.] [Obs.]
CALLID: Characterized by cunning or shrewdness; crafty. [R.]
COMMENTER: One who makes or writes comments; a commentator; an annotator.
CARBIMIDE: The technical name for isocyanic acid. See under Isocyanic.
COMETARY: Pertaining to, or resembling, a comet. Cheyne.
CORROSION: The action or effect of corrosive agents, or the process ofcorrosive change; as, the rusting of iron is a variety of corrosion.Corrosion is a particular species of dissolution of bodies, either byan acid or a saline menstruum. John Quincy.
CORM: A solid bulb-shaped root, as of the crocus. See Bulb.
COLDNESS: The state or quality of being cold.
COURTER: One who courts; one who plays the lover, or who solicits inmarriage; one who flatters and cajoles. Sherwood.
CROSSBILL: A bill brought by a defendant, in an equity or chancery suit,against the plaintiff, respecting the matter in question in thatsuit. Bouvier.
CROSSOPTERYGIAN: Of or pertaining to the Crossopterygii.-- n.
CORNIST: A performer on the cornet or horn.
COVENANTOR: The party who makes a covenant. Burrill.
COGWHEEL: A wheel with cogs or teeth; a gear wheel. See Illust. ofGearing.
CESSATION: A ceasing of discontinuance, as of action, whether termporaryor final; a stop; as, a cessation of the war.The temporary cessation of the papal iniquities. Motley.The day was yearly observed for a festival by cessation from labor.Sir J. Hayward.Cessation of arms (Mil.), an armistice, or truce, agreed to by thecommanders of armies, to give time for a capitulation, or for otherpurposes.
CHLOROPLASTID: A granule of chlorophyll; -- also called chloroleucite.
COCHINEAL FIG: A plant of Central and Southern Anerica, of the Cactus familly,extensively cultivated for the sake of the cochineal insect, whichlives on it.
CORRUGATE: Wrinkled; crumpled; furrowed; contracted into ridges andfurrows.
CORNICULUM: A small hornlike part or process.
CONSANGUINITY: The relation of person by blood, is distinction from affinityor relation by marriage; blood relationship; as, linealconsanguinity; collateral consanguinity.Invoking aid by the ties of consanguinity. Prescott.
CAVATINA: Originally, a melody of simpler form than the aria; a songwithout a second part and a da capo; -- a term now variously andvaguely used.
CHLOROCRUORIN: A green substance, supposed to be the cause of the green colorof the blood in some species of worms. Ray Lankester.
CHICKAREE: The American red squirrel (Sciurus Hudsonius); -- so calledfrom its cry.
CINNAMYL: The hypothetical radical, (C6H5.C2H2)2C, of cinnamic compounds.[Formerly written also cinnamule.]
CRANIOCLASM: The crushing of a child's head, as with the cranioclast orcraniotomy forceps in cases of very difficult delivery. Dunglison.
CAIMACAM: The governor of a sanjak or district in Turkey.
CAPELLANE: The curate of a chapel; a chaplain. [Obs.] Fuller.
CURIAL: Of or pertaining to the papal curia; as, the curial etiquetteof the Vatican. -- n.
COBRA DE CAPELLO: The hooded snake (Naia tripudians), a highly venomous serpentinhabiting India.
COWLIKE: Resembling a cow.With cowlike udders and with oxlike eyes. Pope.
CEREBRIFORM: Like the brain in form or substance.
COMPLACENTIAL: Marked by, or causing, complacence. [Obs.] "Complacentiallove." Baxter.
CALEDONIA: The ancient Latin name of Scotland; -- still used in poetry.
CURTESY: the life estate which a husband has in the lands of hisdeceased wife, which by the common law takes effect where he has hadissue by her, born alive, and capable of inheriting the lands. Mozley& W.
CLATCH: To daub or smear, as with lime; to make or finish in a slipshodway. [Scot.]
CONDUCTIVITY: The quality or power of conducting, or of receiving andtransmitting, as, the conductivity of a nerve. Thermal conductivity(Physics), the quantity of heat that passes in unit time through unitarea of plate whose thickness is unity, when its opposite facesdiffer in temperature by one degree. J. D. Everett.-- Thermometic conductivity (Physics), the thermal conductivity whenthe unit of heat employed is the heat required to raise unit volumeof the substance one degree.
CRASE: To break in pieces; to crack. [Obs.] "The pot was crased."Chaucer.
CALORIC: The principle of heat, or the agent to which the phenomena ofheat and combustion were formerly ascribed; -- not now used inscientific nomenclature, but sometimes used as a general term forheat.Caloric expands all bodies. Henry.
COTTONADE: A somewhat stoun and thick fabric of cotton.
CHYLACEOUS: Possessed of the properties of chyle; consisting of chyle.
CRACK-BRAINED: Having an impaired intellect; whimsical; crazy. Pope.
CALCULATING: The act or process of making mathematical computations or ofestimating results.
CLYSMIAN: Connected with, or related to, the deluge, or to a cataclysm;as, clysmian changes. Smart.
CHURCHYARD: The ground adjoining a church, in which the dead are buried; acemetery.Like graves in the holy churchyard. Shak.
COMPACTLY: In a compact manner; with close union of parts; densely;tersely.
CHORDATA: A comprehensive division of animals including all Vertebratatogether with the Tunicata, or all those having a dorsal nervouscord.
CLONIC: Having an irregular, convulsive motion. Dunglison. Clonicspasm. (Med.) See under Spasm.
COMPREHENSIBLENESS: The quality of being comprehensible; comprehensibility.
CONDUCE: To lead or tend, esp. with reference to a favorable ordesirable result; to contribute; -- usually followed by to or toward.He was sensible how much such a union would conduce to the happinessof both. Macaulay.The reasons you allege do more conduce To the hot passion ofdistemper'd blood. Shak.
CONSTAT: A certificate showing what appears upon record touching amatter in question.
CREPITATE: To make a series of small, sharp, rapidly repeated explosionsor sounds, as salt in fire; to crackle; to snap.
CONSTANT: Remaining unchanged or invariable, as a quantity, forc, law,etc.
CHROMOLITHOGRAPHER: One who is engaged in chromolithography.
COENDOO: The Brazilian porcupine (Cercolades, or Sphingurus,prehensiles), remarkable for its prehensile tail.
CALCIFIC: Calciferous. Specifically: (Zoöl.) of or pertaining to hteportion of the which forms the eggshell in birds and reptiles.Huxley.
COLOR: An apparent right; as where the defendant in trespass gave tothe plaintiff an appearance of title, by stating his title specially,thus removing the cause from the jury to the court. Blackstone.
CAPSICINE: A valatile alkaloid extracted from Capsicum annuum or fromcapsicin.
CROSSBAR: A transverse bar or piece, as a bar across a door, or as theiron bar or stock which passes through the shank of an anchor toinsure its turning fluke down. Russell. Crossbar shot, a projectilewhich folds into a sphere for loading, but on leaving the gun expandsto a cross with a quarter ball at the end of each arm; -- used innaval actions for cutting the enemy's rigging.
CONTEMPTUOUSNESS: Disposition to or manifestion of contempt; insolence;haughtiness.
COCKATEEL: An Australian parrot (Calopsitta Novæ-Hollandiæ); -- so calledfrom its note.
CANTHARIS: A beetle (Lytta, or Cantharis, vesicatoria), having anelongated cylindrical body of a brilliant green color, and a nauseousodor; the blister fly or blister beetle, of the apothecary; -- alsocalled Spanish fly. Many other species of Lytta, used for the samepurpose, take the same name. See Blister beetle, under Blister. Theplural form in usually applied to the dried insects used in medicine.
CHIRP: To make a shop, sharp, cheerful, as of small birds or crickets.
CHORALIST: A singer or composer of chorals.
CORF: A native or inhabitant of Corfu, an island in the MediterraneanSea.
CITTERN: An instrument shaped like a lute, but strung with wire andplayed with a quill or plectrum. [Written also cithern.] Shak.
CASTLE-GUARD: A tax or imposition an a dwelling within a certain distance ofa castle, for the purpose of maintaining watch and ward in it;castle-ward.
CAROTIN: A red crystallizable tasteless substance, extracted from thecarrot.
COQUETRY: Attempts to attract admoration, notice, or love, for the meregratification of vanity; trifling in love. "Little affectations ofcoquetry." Addison.
CARAVANEER: The leader or driver of the camels in caravan.
CUCUMBER: A creeping plant, and its fruit, of several species of thegenus Cucumis, esp. Cucumis sativus, the unripe fruit of which iseaten either fresh or picked. Also, similar plants or fruits ofseveral other genera. See below. Bitter cucumber (Bot.), theCitrullus or Cucumis Colocynthis. SeeColocynth.-- Cucumber beetle. (Zoöl.) (a) A small, black flea-beetle(Crepidodera cucumeris), which destroys the leaves of cucumber,squash, and melon vines. (b) The squash beetle.-- Cucumber tree.(a) A large ornamental or shade tree of the genusMagnolia (M. acuminata), so called from a slight resemblance of itsyoung fruit to a small cucumber. (b) An East Indian plant (AverrhoaBilimbi) which produces the fruit known as bilimbi.-- Jamaica cucumber, Jerusalem cucumber, the prickly-fruited gherkin(Cucumis Anguria).-- Snake cucumber, a species (Cucumis flexuosus) remarkable for itslong, curiously-shaped fruit.-- Squirting cucumber, a plant (Ecbalium Elaterium) whose small ovalfruit separates from the footstalk when ripe and expels its seeds andjuice with considerable force through the opening thus made. SeeElaterium.-- Star cucumber,a climbing weed (Sicyos angulatus) with pricklyfruit.
CARNEOUS: Consisting of, or like, flesh; carnous; fleshy. "Carneousfibers." Ray.
CURVIROSTRES: A group of passerine birds, including the creepers andnuthatches.
CESPITOUS: Pertaining to, consisting, of resembling, turf; turfy.A cespitous or turfy plant has many stems from the same root, usuallyforming a close, thick carpet of matting. Martyn.
CINNOLINE: A nitrogenous organic base, C8H6N2, analogous to quinoline,obtained from certain complex diazo compounds.
CAPELLE: The private orchestra or band of a prince or of a church.
CURRY: A kind of sauce much used in India, containing garlic, pepper,ginger, and other strong spices.
CALIBRATION: The process of estimating the caliber a tube, as of athermometer tube, in order to graduate it to a scale of degrees;also, more generally, the determination of the true value of thespaces in any graduated instrument.
CONFITEOR: A form of prayer in which public confession of sins is made.
COELODONT: Having hollow teeth; -- said of a group lizards.-- n.
COTTONSEED MEAL: A meal made from hulled cotton seeds after the oil has beenexpressed.
CROSS-BIRTH: Any preternatural labor, in whiche the boly of the child liesacross the pelvis of the mother, so that the shoulder, arm, or trunkis the part first presented at the mouth of the uterus.
COMMONTY: A common; a piece of land in which two or more persons have acommon right. Bell.
CREAK: To make a prolonged sharp grating or ssqueaking sound, as bythe friction of hard substances; as, shoes creak.The creaking locusts with my voice conspire. Dryden.Doors upon their hinges creaked. Tennyson.
CONTINENTLY: In a continent manner; chastely; moderately; temperately.
CHEMICAL: Pertaining to chemistry; characterized or produced by theforces and operations of chemistry; employed in the processes ofchemistry; as, chemical changes; chemical comnbinations. Chemicalattraction or affinity. See under Attraction.
CARTON: Pasteboard for paper boxes; also, a pasteboard box. Cartonpierre (, a species of papier-maché, imitating stone or bronzesculpture. Knight.
COURTLINESS: The quality of being courtly; elegance or dignity of manners.
CURTSY: Same as Courtesy, an act of respect.
CALIPEE: A part of a turtle which is attached to the lower shell. Itcontains a fatty and gelatinous substance of a light yellowish color,much esteemed as a delicacy. Thackeray.
COWLSTAFF: A staff or pole on which a vessel is supported between twopersons. Suckling.
CARPAL: Of or pertaining to the carpus, or wrist.-- n.
CONFABULATORY: Of the nature of familiar talk; in the form of a dialogue.Weever.
CATAPETALOUS: Having the petals held together by stamens, which grow to theirbases, as in the mallow.
COMPRESS: A folded piece of cloth, pledget of lint, etc., used to coverthe dressing of wounds, and so placed as, by the aid of a bandage, tomake due pressure on any part.
CATHEAD: A projecting piece of timber or iron near the bow of vessel, towhich the anchor is hoisted and secured.
CHIMAERA: A cartilaginous fish of several species, belonging to the orderHolocephali. The teeth are few and large. The head is furnished withappendages, and the tail terminates in a point.
COMMUTER: One who commutes; especially, one who commutes in traveling.
CARDIOGRAM: The curve or tracing made by a cardiograph.
CARTESIAN: Of or pertaining to the French philosopher René Descartes, orhis philosophy.The Cartesion argument for reality of matter. Sir W. Hamilton.Cartesian coördinates (Geom), distance of a point from lines orplanes; -- used in a system of representing geometric quantities,invented by Descartes.-- Cartesian devil, a small hollow glass figure, used in connectionwith a jar of water having an elastic top, to illustrate the effectof the compression or expansion of air in changing the specificgravity of bodies.-- Cartesion oval (Geom.), a curve such that, for any point of thecurve mr + m'r' = c, where r and r' are the distances of the pointfrom the two foci and m, m' and c are constant; -- used by Descartes.
COPPER: the boilers in the galley for cooking; as, a ship's coppers.
CUBILOSE: A mucilagenous secretion of certain birds found as thecharacteristic ingredient of edible bird's-nests.
CATELECTRODE: The negative electrode or pole of a voltaic battery. Faraday.
CARPETBAG: A portable bag for travelers; -- so called because originallymade of carpet.
COUSINHOOD: The state or condition of a cousin; also, the collective bodyof cousins; kinsfolk.
CURIALIST: One who belongs to the ultramontane party in the Latin Church.Shipley.
CAMIS: A light, loose dress or robe. [Also written camus.] [Obs.]All in a camis light of purple silk. Spenser.
CALLIDITY: Acuteness of discernment; cunningness; shrewdness. [R.]Her eagly-eyed callidity. C. Smart.
CROSS-SPRINGER: One of the ribs in a groined arch, springing from the cornersin a diagonal direction.
CHERUP: To make a short, shrill, cheerful sound; to chirp. See Chirrup."Cheruping birds." Drayton.
COVER CROP: A catch crop planted, esp. in orchards. as a protection to thesoil in winter, as well as for the benefit of the soil when plowedunder in spring.
CEROPLASTIC: The art of modeling in wax.
CONCHIFERA: That class of Mollusca which includes the bivalve shells; theLamellibranchiata. See Mollusca.
CASCADE SYSTEM: A system or method of connecting and operating two inductionmotors so that the primary circuit of one is connected to thesecondary circuit of the other, the primary circuit of the latterbeing connected to the source of supply; also, a system of electrictraction in which motors so connected are employed. The cascadesystem is also called tandem, or concatenated, system; the connectiona cascade, tandem, or concatenated, connection, or a concatenation;and the control of the motors so obtained a tandem, or concatenation,control. In the cascade system of traction the cascade connection isused for starting and for low speeds up to half speed. For full speedthe short-circuited motor is cut loose from the other motor and iseither left idle or (commonly) connected direct to the line.
CALCAREOUS: Partaking of the nature ofcalcite or calcium carbonate;consisting of, or containg, calcium carbonate or carbonate of lime.Clcareous spar. See as Calcite.
CIRCUMAMBAGE: A roundabout or indirect course; indirectness. [Obs.] S.Richardson.
CREMATE: To burn; to reduce to ashes by the action of fire, eitherdirectly or in an oven or retort; to incremate or incinerate; as, tocremate a corpse, instead of burying it.
COUNTERWORK: To work in oppositeion to; to counteract.That counterworksh folly and caprice. Pope.
CIRCUIT: To move in a circle; to go round; to circulate. [Obs.] J.Philips.
CATA: The Latin and English form of a Greek preposition, used as aprefix to signify down, downward, under, against, contrary or opposedto, wholly, completely; as in cataclysm, catarrh. It sometimes dropsthe final vowel, as in catoptric; and is sometimes changed to cath,as in cathartic, catholic.
CHECK: A word of warning denoting that the king is in danger; such amenace of a player's king by an adversary's move as would, if it wereany other piece, expose it to immediate capture. A king so menaced issaid to be in check, and must be made safe at the next move.
CIGARETTE: A little cigar; a little fine tobacco rolled in paper forsmoking.
CANTABRIGIAN: A native or resident of Cambridge; esp. a student or graduateof the university of Cambridge, England.
CONVERTIBLENESS: The state of being convertible; convertibility.
CHESTEYN: The chestnut tree. [Obs.]Wilwe, elm, plane, assch, box, chesteyn. Chaucer.
CRIMINOUS: Criminal; involving great crime or grave charges; very wicked;heinous. [Obs.] Holland.-- Crim"i*nous*ly, adv..-- Crim"i*nous*ness,n. [Obs.]
CITTERN-HEAD: Blockhead; dunce; -- so called because the handle of a citternusually ended with a carved head. Marsion
CADMIA: An oxide of zinc which collects on the sides of furnaces wherezinc is sublimed. Formerly applied to the mineral calamine.
COACTION: Force; compulsion, either in restraining or impelling. Sojth.
CLAVELLATED: Said of potash, probably in reference to its having beenobtained from billets of wood by burning. [Obs.]
COMPACTION: The act of making compact, or the state of being compact.[Obs.] Bacon.
CONCENTRIC: That which has a common center with something else.Its pecular relations to its concentrics. Coleridge.
CIVIL SERVICE REFORM: The substitution of business principles and methods forpolitical methods in the conduct of the civil service. esp. the meritsystem instead of the spoils system in making appointments to office.
COMMINGLER: One that commingles; specif., a device for noiseless heating ofwater by steam, in a vessel filled with a porous mass, as of pebbles.
CARABID: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the genus Carbus or familyCarabidæ.-- n.
CHALCOPYRITE: Copper pyrites, or yellow copper ore; a common ore of opper,containing copper, iron, and sulphur. It occurs massive and intetragonal crystals of a bright brass yellow color.
CRECHE: A public nursery, where the young children of poor women arecared for during the day, while their mothers are at work.
CRYPTOCRYSTALLINE: Indistinctly crystalline; -- applied to rocks and minerals,whose state of aggregation is so fine that no distinct particles arevisible, even under the microscope.
COPY: Manuscript or printed matter to be set up in type; as, theprinters are calling for more copy.
CRANIOMETER: An instrument for measuring the size of skulls.
COMPOST: A mixture for fertilizing land; esp., a composition of varioussubstances (as muck, mold, lime, and stable manure) thoroughlymingled and decomposed, as in a compost heap.And do not spread the compost on the weeds To make them ranker. Shak.
CONVALLAMARIN: A white, crystalline, poisonous substance, regarded as aglucoside, extracted from the lily of the valley (ConvallariaMajalis). Its taste is first bitter, then sweet.
CURR: To coo. [Scot.]The owlets hoot, the owlets curr. Wordsworth.
COBIRON: An andiron with a knob at the top. Bacon.
CONCLUDENCY: Deduction from premises; inference; conclusion. [Obs.] Sir M.Hale.
COMPTIBLE: Accountable; responsible; sensitive. [Obs.]I am very comptible even to the least sinister usage. Shak.
COMMANDRESS: A woman invested with authority to command. Hooker.
COLLUDER: One who conspires in a fraud.
CARBAZOTIC: Containing, or derived from, carbon and nitrogen. Carbazoticacid (Chem.), picric acid. See under Picric.
CONCHAL: Pertaining to the concha, or external ear; as, the conchalcartilage.
CLEFTGRAFT: To ingraft by cleaving the stock and inserting a scion.Mortimer.
CEREBRIPETAL: Applied to those nerve fibers which go from the spinal cord tothe brain and so transfer sensations (centripetal impressions) fromthe exterior inwards.
CONVERSIBLE: Capable of being converted or reversed. Hammond.
CORDONNET: Doubled and twisted thread, made of coarse silk, and used fortassels, fringes, etc. McElrath.
CRUSADING: Of or pertaining to a crusade; as, a crusading spirit.
COLLARDS: Young cabbage, used as "greens"; esp. a kind cultivated forthat purpose; colewort. [Colloq. Souther U. S.]
CUP-GALL: A kind of oak-leaf gall. See Gall.
COLLYBIST: A money changer. [Obs.]In the face of these guilty collybists. Bp. Hall.
COMPLEXIONALLY: Constitutionally. [R.]Though corruptible, not complexionally vicious. Burke.
CALICOBACK: Relating to, or resembling, a cup; also improperly used forcalycular, calyculate.
CARNATE: Invested with, or embodied in, flesh.
CHOKEDAR: A watchman; an officer of customs or police. [India]
CLICHE: A stereotype plate or any similar reproduction of ornament, orlettering, in relief. Cliché casting, a mode of obtaining animpression from a die or woodcut, or the like, by striking itsuddenly upon metal which has been fused and is just becoming solid;also, the casting so obtained.
CAUSATIVE: A word which expresses or suggests a cause.
CORRIGIBILITY: Quality of being corrigible; capability of being corrected;corrigibleness.
CICERONIANISM: Imitation of, or resemblance to, the style or action Cicero; aCiceronian phrase or expression. "Great study in Ciceronianism, thechief abuse of Oxford." Sir P. Sidney.
CAROUSINGLY: In the manner of a carouser.
COLOTOMY: An operation for opening the colon
CAMPANULA: A large genus of plants bearing bell-shaped flowers, often ofgreat beauty; -- also called bellflower.
CHILDSHIP: The state or relation of being a child.
CIRCUMJACENCE: Condition of being circumjacent, or of bordering ou every side.
CHANGEABLENESS: The quality of being changeable; fickleness; inconstancy;mutability.
CO-LESSOR: A partner in giving a lease.
COUNTERWHEEL: To cause to wheel or turn in an opposite direction.
CHIRPING: Cheering; enlivening.He takes his chirping pint, he cracks his jokes. Pope.
COSUPREME: A partaker of supremacy; one jointly supreme. Shak.
CHIVY: To goad, drive, hunt, throw, or pitch. [Slang, Eng.] Dickens.
COPEMAN: A chapman; a dealer; a merchant. [Obs.]He would have sold his part of paradise For ready money, had he met acopeman. B. Jonson.
CHALCHIHUITL: The Mexican name for turquoise. See Turquoise.
CHILOMA: The tumid upper lip of certain mammals, as of a camel.
CARDIOGRAPH: An instrument which, when placed in contact with the chest,will register graphically the comparative duration and intensity ofthe heart's movements.
CATHERINE WHEEL: Same as Rose window and Wheel window. Called also Catherine-wheel window.
COHEIRSHIP: The state of being a coheir.
CO-SUFFERER: One who suffers with another. Wycherley.
COMMENSURABLE: Having a common measure; capable of being exactly measured bythe same number, quantity, or measure.-- Com*men"su*ra*ble*ness, n. Commensurable numbers or quantities(Math.), those that can be exactly expressed by some common unit;thus a foot and yard are commensurable, since both can be expressedin terms of an inch, one being 12 inches, the other 36 inches.-- Numbers, or Quantities, commensurable in power, those whosesquares are commensurable.
CAEN STONE: A cream-colored limestone for building, found near Caen,France.
CONGREGATION: The whole body of the Jewish people; -- called alsoCongregation of the Lord.It is a sin offering for the congregation. Lev. iv. 21.
COME-OUTER: One who comes out or withdraws from a religious or otherorganization; a radical reformer. [Colloq. U. S.]
CHANGELESS: That can not be changed; constant; as, a changeless purpose.-- Change"less*ness, n.
CONCHA: The plain semidome of an apse; sometimes used for the entireapse.
CEPHEUS: (Astron.) A northern constellation near the pole. Its head,which is in the Milky Way, is marked by a triangle formed by threestars of the fourth magnitude. See Cassiopeia.
CATENATE: To connect, in a series of links or ties; to chain. E. Darwin.
COCKFIGHTING: The act or practice of pitting gamecocks to fight.
CUINAGE: The stamping of pigs of tin, by the proper officer, with thearms of the duchy of Cornwall.
CHAMPIONSHIP: State of being champion; leadership; supremancy.
CHAINWORK: Work looped or linked after the manner of a chain; chain stitchwork.
COGNIZOR: One who ackowledged the right of the plaintiff or cognizee in afine; the defendant. Blackstone.
CHAMFRON: The frontlet, or head armor, of a horse. [Written alsochampfrain and chamfrain.]
COPULATIVE: Serving to couple, unite, or connect; as, a copulativeconjunction like "and".
COLOGNE: A perfumed liquid, composed of alcohol and certain aromaticoils, used in the toilet; -- called also cologne water and eau decologne.
CROOKES TUBE: A vacuum tube in which the exhaustion is carried to a very highdegree, with the production of a distinct class of effects; -- socalled from W. Crookes who introduced it.
CANTINIERE: A woman who carries a canteen for soldiers; a vivandière.
COLORATURE: Vocal music colored, as it were, by florid ornaments, runs, orrapid passages.
CONIFERIN: A glucoside extracted from the cambium layer of coniferoustrees as a white crystalline substance.
CARYATID: (Arch.) A draped female figure supporting an entablature, inthe place of a column or pilaster.
CINCHONACEOUS: Allied or pertaining to cinchona, or to the plants that produceit.
COLERIDGIAN: Pertaining to Samuel Taylor Coleridge, or to his poetry ormetaphysics.
CAPACIOUSNESS: The quality of being capacious, as of a vessel, a reservoir abay, the mind, etc.
CREAMY: Full of, or containing, cream; resembling cream, in nature,appearance, or taste; creamlike; unctuous. "Creamy bowis." Collins."Lines of creamy spray." Tennyson. "Your creamy words but cozen."Beau & Fl.
CAMPANERO: The bellbird of South America. See Bellbird.
COVERING: Anything which covers or conceals, as a roof, a screen, awrapper, clothing, etc.Noah removed the covering of the ark. Gen. viii. 13.They cause the naked to lodge without clothing, that they have nocovering in the cold. Job. xxiv. 7.A covering over the well's mouth. 2 Sam. xvii. 19.
CUPEL: A shallow porus cup, used in refining precious metals, commonlymade of bone ashes (phosphate of lime). [Written also coppel.] Cupeldust, powder used in purifying metals.
COMMENSATION: Commensality. [Obs.]Daniel . . . declined pagan commensation. Sir T. Browne.
CAULICLE: A short caulis or stem, esp. the rudimentary stem seen in theembryo of seed; -- otherwise called a radicle.
CROSS-DAYS: The three days preceding the Feast of the Ascension.
CRUOR: The coloring matter of the blood; the clotted portion ofcoagulated blood, containing the coloring matter; gore.
COURLAN: A South American bird, of the genus Aramus, allied to therails.
CIRCUMGYRATION: The act of turning, rolling, or whirling round.A certain turbulent and irregular circumgyration. Holland.
CONSTANTIA: A superior wine, white and red, from Constantia, in CapeColony.
CHARLATAN: One who prates much in his own favor, and makes unwarrantablepretensions; a quack; an impostor; an empiric; a mountebank.
CONCERTINA: A small musical imstrument on the principle of the accordion.It is a small elastic box, or bellows, having free reeds on theinside, and keys and handles on the outside of each of the twohexagonal heads.
CLUMSINESS: The quality of being clusy.The drudging part of life is chiefly owing to clumsiness andignorance. Collier.
COCKUP: A large, highly esteemed, edible fish of India (Latescalcarifer); -- also called begti.
COHEIR: A joint heir; one of two or more heirs; one of several entitledto an inheritance.
CHAFER: A kind of beetle; the cockchafer. The name is also applied toother species; as, the rose chafer.
CELLEPORE: A genus of delicate branching corals, made up of minute cells,belonging to the Bryozoa.
CANKERWORM: The larva of two species of geometrid moths which are veryinjurious to fruit and shade trees by eating, and often entirelydestroying, the foliage. Other similar larvæ are also calledcankerworms.
CROUSTADE: Bread baked in a mold, and scooped out, to serve minces upon.Bishop.
CONCLAMATION: An outcry or shout of many together. [R.]Before his funeral conclamation. May (Lucan).
COMMENDAM: A vacant living or benefice commended to a cleric (usually abishop) who enjoyed the revenue until a pastor was provided. A livingso held was said to be held in commendam. The practice was abolishedby law in 1836.There was [formerly] some sense for commendams. Selden.Partnership in commendam. See under Partnership.
CHRISTLIKE: Resembling Christ in character, actions, etc.-- Christ"like`ness, n.
CABOTAGE: Navigation along the coast; the details of coast pilotage.
CEPHALOUS: Having a head; -- applied chiefly to the Cephalata, a divisionof mollusks.
CEROSIN: A waxy substance obtained from the bark of the sugar cane, andcrystallizing in delicate white laminæ.
CRESSY: Abounding in cresses.The cressy islets white in flower. Tennyson.
CONSIGNIFY: To signify or denote in combination with something else.The cipher . . . only serves to connote and consignify, and to changethe value or the figures. Horne Tooke.
CONCHOIDAL: Having elevations or depressions in form like one half of abivalve shell; -- applied principally to a surface produced byfracture.
CONTEND: To struggle for; to contest. [R.]Carthage shall contend the world with Rome.Dryden.
COINHERE: To inhere or exist together, as in one substance. Sir W.Hamilton.
COINSURANCE: Insurance jointly with another or others; specif., that systemof fire insurance in which the insurer is treated as insuring himselfto the extent of that part of the risk not covered by his policy, sothat any loss is apportioned between him and the insurance company onthe principle of average, as in marine insurance or between otherinsurers.
CARBAMINE: An isocyanide of a hydrocarbon radical. The carbamines areliquids, usually colorless, and of unendurable odor.
COMPLEXNESS: The state of being complex; complexity. A. Smith.
CASUALLY: Without design; accidentally; fortuitously; by chance;occasionally.
CIRCUMSPECTIVE: Looking around everi way; cautious; careful of consequences;watchful of danger. "Circumspective eyes." Pope.
CHORALLY: In the manner of a chorus; adapted to be sung by a choir; inharmony.
CANDEROS: An East Indian resin, of a pellucid white color, from whichsmall ornaments and toys are sometimes made.
CRANIOFACIAL: Of or pertaining to the cranium and face; as, the craniofacialangle.
COLORADOITE: Mercury telluride, an iron-black metallic mineral, found inColorado.
CONGEAL: To grow hard, stiff, or thick, from cold or other causes; tobecome solid; to freeze; to cease to flow; to run cold; to bechilled.
CLEW: To move of draw (a sail or yard) by means of the clew garnets,clew lines, etc.; esp. to draw up the clews of a square sail to theyard. To clew down (Naut.), to force (a yard) down by hauling on theclew lines.-- To clew up (Naut.), to draw (a sail) up to the yard, as forfurling.
CALADE: A slope or declivity in a manege ground down which a horse ismade to gallop, to give suppleness to his haunches.
COMPEAR: To appear in court personally or by attorney. [Scot]
CAPTOR: One who captures any person or thing, as a prisoner or a prize.
CARTILAGINOUS: Having the skeleton in the state of cartilage, the bonescontaining little or no calcareous matter; said of certain fishes, asthe sturgeon and the sharks.
COUNTRETAILLE: A counter tally; correspondence (in sound). [Obs.] At thecountretaille, in return. Chaucer.
CENSUAL: Relating to, or containing, a census.He caused the whole realm to be described in a censual roll. Sir R.Baker.
CHRYSENE: One of the higher aromatic hydrocarbons of coal tar, allied tonapthalene and anthracene. It is a white crystalline substance,C18H12, of strong blue fluorescence, but generally colored yellow byimpurities.
CONNOTATIVELY: In a connotative manner; expressing connotation.
CANDIDATE: One who offers himself, or is put forward by others, as asuitable person or an aspirant or contestant for an office,privilege, or honor; as, a candidate for the office of governor; acandidate for holy orders; a candidate for scholastic honors.
COMMENSURABLY: In a commensurable manner; so as to be commensurable.
CRASPEDOTA: The hydroid or naked-eyed medusæ. See Hydroidea.
CRYSTALLITE: A minute mineral form like those common in glassy volcanicrocks and some slags, not having a definite crystalline outline andnot referable to any mineral species, but marking the first step inthe crystallization process. According to their form crystallites arecalled trichites, belonites, globulites, etc.
CLAW: A slender appendage or process, formed like a claw, as the baseof petals of the pink. Gray. Claw hammer, a hammer with one end ofthe metallic head cleft for use in extracting nails, etc.-- Claw hammer coat, a dress coat of the swallowtail pattern.[Slang] -- Claw sickness, foot rot, a disease affecting sheep.
CAMERALISTIC: Of or pertaining to finance and public revenue.
CHYLIFACTIVE: Producing, or converting into, chyle; having the power to formchyle.
CONDESCENSION: The act of condescending; voluntary descent from one's rank ordignity in intercourse with an inferior; courtesy toward inferiors.It forbids pride . . . and commands humility, modesty, andcondescension to others. Tillotson.Such a dignity and condescension . . . as are suitable to a superiornature. Addison.
CHANGEFUL: Full of change; mutable; inconstant; fickle; uncertain. Pope.His course had been changeful. Motley.-- Change"ful*ly, adv.-- Change"ful*ness, n.
CROCK: The loose black particles collected from combustion, as on potsand kettles, or in a chimney; soot; smut; also, coloring matter whichrubs off from cloth.
CONTAMINATE: To soil, stain, or corrupt by contact; to tarnish; to sully; totaint; to pollute; to defile.Shall we now Contaminate our figures with base bribes Shak.I would neither have simplicity imposed upon, nor virtuecontaminated. Goldsmith.
CONVEXEDLY: In a convex form; convexly. Sir T. Browne.
COURTBRED: Bred, or educated, at court; polished; courtly.
CIRCUMFUSILE: Capable of being poured or spread round. "Circumfusile gold."Pope.
CRUX: Anything that is very puzzling or difficult to explain. Dr.Sheridan.The perpetual crux of New Testament chronologists. Strauss.
CHRONOMETRY: The art of measuring time; the measuring of time by periods ordivisions.
CICISBEISM: The state or conduct of a cicisbeo.
CORE: A body of individuals; an assemblage. [Obs.]He was in a core of people. Bacon.
CRETACEOUSLY: In a chalky manner; as chalk.
CHAMADE: A signal made for a parley by beat of a drum.They beat the chamade, and sent us carte blanche. Addison.
CADE: Bred by hand; domesticated; petted.He brought his cade lamb with him. Sheldon.
CHIDER: One who chides or quarrels. Shak.
CROMLECH: A monument of rough stones composed of one or more large onessupported in a horizontal position upon others. They are foundchiefly in countris inhabited by the ancient Celts, and are of aperiod anterior to the introduction of Christianity into thesecountries.
COMPULSATORY: Operating with force; compelling; forcing; constraininig;resulting from, or enforced by, compulsion. [R.]To recover of us, by strong hand And terms compulsatory, thoseforesaid lands. Shak.
CIRCUMSTANCE: Condition in regard to worldly estate; state of property;situation; surroundings.When men are easy in their circumstances, they are naturally enemiesto innovations. Addison.Not a circumstance, of no account. [Colloq.] -- Under thecircumstances, taking all things into consideration.
CURT: Characterized by exessive brevity; short; rudely concise; as,curt limits; a curt answer.The curt, yet comprehensive reply. W. Irving.
CONNUBIAL: Of or pertaining to marriage, or the marriage state; conjugal;nuptial.Nor Eve the rites Mysterious of connubial love refused. Milton.Kind, connubial tenderness. Goldsmith.
CICATRICLE: The germinating point in the embryo of a seed; the point in theyolk of an egg at which development begins.
CARBONARISM: The principles, practices, or organization of the Carbonari.
CLUB-RUSH: A rushlike plant, the reed mace or cat-tail, or some species ofthe genus Scirpus. See Bulrush.
CALIPASH: A part of a turtle which is next to the upper shell. Itcontains a fatty and gelatinous substance of a dull greenish tinge,much esteemed as a delicacy in preparations of turtle.
CONE PULLEY: A pulley for driving machines, etc., having two or more partsor steps of different diameters; a pulley having a conical shape.
COUNTERSECURE: To give additional security to or for. Burke.
CONCAVED: Bowed in the form of an arch; -- called also arched.
CANTON: A song or canto [Obs.]Write loyal cantons of contemned love. Shak.
CEASE: To put a stop to; to bring to an end.But he, her fears to cease Sent down the meek-eyed peace. Milton.Cease, then, this impious rage. Milton
CAMASS: A blue-flowered liliaceous plant (Camassia esculenta) ofnorthwestern America, the bulbs of which are collected for food bythe Indians. [Written also camas, cammas, and quamash.]
CHEETAH: A species of leopard (Cynælurus jubatus) tamed and used forhunting in India. The woolly cheetah of South Africa is C. laneus.[Written also chetah.]
CHAIN STITCH: A stitch in which the looping of the thread or threads forms achain on the under side of the work; the loop stitch, asdistinguished from the lock stitch. See Stitch.
CURTILAGE: A yard, courtyard, or piece of ground, included within thefence surrounding a dwelling house. Burrill.
COSIGNITARY: Signing some important public document with another or withothers; as, a treaty violated by one of the cosignitary powers.
COMPENDIOUSNESS: The state or quality of being compendious.
CURVATURE: The amount of degree of bending of a mathematical curve, or thetendency at any point to depart from a tangent drawn to the curve atthat point. Aberrancy of curvature (Geom.), the deviation of a curvefrom a curcular form. -Absolute curvature. See under Absolute.-- Angle of curvature (Geom.), one that expresses the amount ofcurvature of a curve.-- Chord of curvature. See under Chord.-- Circle of curvature. See Osculating circle of a curve, underCircle.-- Curvature of the spine (Med.), an abnormal curving of the spine,especially in a lateral direction.-- Radius of curvature, the radius of the circle of curvature, orosculatory circle, at any point of a curve.
CHAINLESS: Having no chain; not restrained or fettered. "The chainlessmind." Byron.
COWPOX: A pustular eruptive disease of the cow, which, whencommunicated to the human system, as by vaccination, protects fromthe smallpox; vaccinia; -- called also kinepox, cowpock, andkinepock. Dunglison.
COMETOLOGY: The department of astronomy relating to comets.
COAMINGS: Raised pieces of wood of iron around a hatchway, skylight, orother opening in the deck, to prevent water from running bellow; esp.the fore-and-aft pieces of a hatchway frame as distinguished from thetransverse head ledges. [Written also combings.]
CHEWINK: An american bird (Pipilo erythrophthalmus) of the Finch family,so called from its note; -- called also towhee bunting and groundrobin.
CYCLING: The act, art, or practice, of riding a cycle, esp. a bicycle ortricycle.
CORONOID: Resembling the beak of a crow; as, the coronoid process of thejaw, or of the ulna.
CHILDBIRTH: The act of bringing forth a child; travail; labor. Jer. Taylor.
CANDIOT: Of or pertaining to Candia; Cretary.
CEMENTAL: Of or pertaining to cement, as of a tooth; as, cemental tubes.R. Owen.
CAMEO: A carving in relief, esp. one on a small scale used as a jewelfor personal adornment, or like.
CEDILLA: A mark placed under the letter c [thus, ç], to show that it isto be sounded like s, as in façade.
CAPELLMEISTER: The musical director in royal or ducal chapel; a choirmaster.[Written also kepellmeister.]
CONSUMPTIVELY: In a way tending to or indication consumption. Beddoes.
CREMAILLERE: An indented or zigzaged line of intrenchment.
CERINTHIAN: One of an ancient religious sect, so called fron Cerinthus, aJew, who attempted to unite the doctrines of Christ with the opinionsof the Jews and Gnostics. Hook.
CONVERSION: An appropriation of, and dealing with the property of anotheras if it were one's own, without right; as, the conversion of ahorse.Or bring my action of conversion And trover for my goods. Hudibras.
CRESCENDO: With a constantly increasing volume of voice; with graduallyincreasing strength and fullness of tone; -- a direction for theperformance of music, indicated by the mark, or by writing the wordon the score.
CORANACH: A lamentation for the dead; a dirge. [Written also coranich,corrinoch, coronach, cronach, etc.] [Scot.]
CHAETETES: A genus of fossil corals, common in the lower Silurianlimestones.
CHANSON DE GESTE: Any Old French epic poem having for its subject events orexploits of early French history, real or legendary, and writtenoriginally in assonant verse of ten or twelve syllables. The mostfamous one is the Chanson de Roland.
CULPE: Blameworthiness. [Obs.]Banished out of the realme . . . without culpe. E. Hall.
CONGRUENT: Possessing congruity; suitable; agreeing; corresponding.The congruent and harmonious fitting of parts in a sentence. B.Jonson.Congruent figures (Geom.), concurring figures.
CIRCUS: A level oblong space surrounded on three sides by seats ofwood, earth, or stone, rising in tiers one above another, and dividedlengthwise through the middle by a barrier around which the track orcourse was laid out. It was used for chariot races, games, and publicshows.
COSTER: One who hawks about fruit, green vegetables, fish, etc.
CHONDROSTEI: An order of fishes, including the sturgeons; -- so namedbecause the skeleton is cartilaginous.
COCKLE: A bivalve mollusk, with radiating ribs, of the genus Cardium,especially C. edule, used in Europe for food; -- sometimes applied tosimilar shells of other genera.
CYMOGRAPH: To trace or copy with a cymograph.
CORTICIFORM: Resembling, or having the form of, bark or rind.
CYNANTHROPY: A kind of madness in which men fancy themselves changed intodogs, and imitate the voice and habits of that animal.
CO-UNE: To combine or unite. [Obs.] "Co-uned together." Feltham.
CYPERACEOUS: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a large family of plants ofwhich the sedge is the type.
CALCEOLARIA: A genus of showy herbaceous or shrubby plant, biought fromSouth America; slipperwort. It has a yellow or purple flower, oftenspotted or striped, the shape of which suggests its name.
CORRECTNESS: The state or quality of being correct; as, the correctness ofopinions or of manners; correctness of taste; correctness in writingor speaking; the correctness of a text or copy.
CORNIFICATION: Conversion into, or formation of, horn; a becoming like horn.
CARBONACEOUS: Pertaining to, containing, or composed of, carbon.
COUNTERGLOW: An exceedingly faint roundish or somewhat oblong nebulous lightnear the ecliptic and opposite the sun, best seen during Septemberand October, when in the constellations Sagittarius and Pisces. Itscause is not yet understood. Called also Gegenschein.
COLEOPTERA: An order of insects having the anterior pair of wings (elytra)hard and horny, and serving as coverings for the posterior pair,which are membranous, and folded transversely under the others whennot in use. The mouth parts form two pairs of jaws (mandibles andmaxillæ) adapted for chewing. Most of the Coleoptera are known asbeetles and weevils.
CYTOPLASM: The substance of the body of a cell, as distinguished from thekaryoplasma, or substance of the nucleus.-- Cy`to*plas"mic (-pl, a.
CAMBIUM: A series of formative cells lying outside of the wood properand inside of the inner bark. The growth of new wood takes place inthe cambium, which is very soft.
CATERY: The place where provisions are deposited. [Obs.]
CHLORATE: A salt of chloric acid; as, chlorate of potassium.
CESSIBLE: Giving way; yielding. [Obs.] -- Ces`si*bil"i*ty, n. [Obs.] SirK. Digby.
CACOTECHNY: A corruption or corrupt state of art. [R.]
CATAMENIAL: Pertaining to the catamenia, or menstrual discharges.
CRITERION: A standard of judging; any approved or established rule ortest, by which facts, principles opinions, and conduct are tried informing a correct judgment respecting them.Of the diseases of the mind there is no criterion. Donne.Inferences founded on such enduring criteria. Sir G. C. Lewis.
CONCHOLOGICAL: Pertaining to, or connected with, conchology.
CATCHER: The player who stands behind the batsman to catch the ball.
CARD: A perforated pasteboard or sheet-metal plate for warp threads,making part of the Jacquard apparatus of a loom. See Jacquard.
CALORIFERE: An apparatus for conveying and distributing heat, especially bymeans of hot water circulating in tubes.
CRUMBLE: To break into small pieces; to cause to fall in pieces.He with his bare wand can unthread thy joints, And crumble all thysinews. Milton.
CATAPASM: A compound medicinal powder, used by the ancients to sprinkleon ulcers, to absorb perspiration, etc. Dunglison.
CONDENSER: An apparatus for receiving and condensing the volatile productsof distillation to a liquid or solid form, by cooling.
CYCLORAMA: A pictorial view which is extended circularly, so that thespectator is surrounded by the objects represented as by things innature. The realistic effect is increased by putting, in the spacebetween the spectator and the picture, things adapted to the scenerepresented, and in some places only parts of these objects, thecompletion of them being carried out pictorially.
COSMOLABE: An instrument resembling the astrolabe, formerly used formeasuring the angles between heavenly bodies; -- called alsopantacosm.
CONGLUTIN: A variety of vegetable casein, resembling legumin, and found inalmonds, rye, wheat, etc.
